post_text: Is there any way to offer cash pay services to someone that has Medicare? To my understanding this is not allowed but is there a way around this? I currently have a total knee patient that would like to pay cash.

comments.text: If the person needs skilled therapy (ie post op care from TKR) you can‚Äôt just get around it by calling it wellness. You can only charge cash for non covered services.

Unfortunately no but you could always convert them into a wellness client once PT is done. I've done that with a lot of my patients. 

I think it's awesome that so many clinicians on here are cash based. But I'm amazed that someone would pay cash pay for post-op total knee rehab when insurance covers it. I feel like most PTs do a pretty good job in this area

full_thread_text:
POST: Is there any way to offer cash pay services to someone that has Medicare? To my understanding this is not allowed but is there a way around this? I currently have a total knee patient that would like to pay cash.

COMMENT 1: If the person needs skilled therapy (ie post op care from TKR) you can‚Äôt just get around it by calling it wellness. You can only charge cash for non covered services.

COMMENT 2: Unfortunately no but you could always convert them into a wellness client once PT is done. I've done that with a lot of my patients. 

I think it's awesome that so many clinicians on here are cash based. But I'm amazed that someone would pay cash pay for post-op total knee rehab when insurance covers it. I feel like most PTs do a pretty good job in this area

post_text: Has anyone gone from cash-based to in-network? I love my clinic and what we do‚Ä¶ but since I hired another therapist I can‚Äôt get enough clientele to make overhead. But then if I switch I feel like I‚Äôm going to end  up like every other mill in my town and I refuse to do that.  But I know others in here do insurance‚Ä¶. I saw my bosses in my old jobs rolling in dough while I was barely make ends meet‚Ä¶. How does insurance reimburse these days?  I have someone trying to convince me to be a multi-specialty clinic because it reimburses more‚Ä¶ is that true? Has anyone done this?

comments.text:
I see this a lot, so I‚Äôll be direct but hopefully helpful.

Most of the time the issue isn‚Äôt cash vs insurance. It‚Äôs that cash practices expect being cash + good clinical care to magically solve hiring and filling schedules. That works when you‚Äôre solo. It breaks the second you hire.

When you were alone, you had low overhead and lots of time. You could network, run workshops, meet people, hustle. Your hire is not going to do that at the same level, and they shouldn‚Äôt be expected to. At that point, you need real systems.

Cash pay clinics that scale well all have a few things in place:
‚Ä¢ Strong sales skills from the first phone call through the eval
‚Ä¢ Clear package presentation (you have to sell packages)
‚Ä¢ Continuity options so people don‚Äôt disappear once pain improves
‚Ä¢ An intentional marketing channel that doesn‚Äôt rely on the owner‚Äôs time

On the insurance side, one thing I saw in the comments stood out. If BCBS reimburses better than your cash rates, that‚Äôs a pricing issue. Your cash rates are too low.

I totally get wanting to help more people, but once you charge anything above $0, you‚Äôre already excluding someone. So you might as well price in a way that lets you run a sustainable business, pay staff well, and not burn out. Don‚Äôt pick prices everyone can afford. Pick prices that support the business and the life you want.

Multi-specialty can reimburse more, but it also adds complexity and doesn‚Äôt fix weak sales or marketing. Plenty of multi-specialty clinics still struggle for the same reasons.

Before jumping in-network, I‚Äôd fix sales, marketing, packaging, and pricing first. Cash pay can work very well, but only when it‚Äôs run intentionally.

in what part of the country are you located?
In network benefits (BCBS) vary a lot depending on location.

I totally get wanting to help more people, but once you charge anything above $0, you‚Äôre already excluding someone. post_text:
Hi! I had someone reach out who was just in an automobile accident last week and was referred to pelvic floor therapy for her concerns. I‚Äôve never treated anyone going through MV insurance - I‚Äôm OON/cash based to begin with. 

Happy to work with her but curious on other perspectives or anything to expect in terms of paper work or billing! 

Thank you in advance to everyone who responds!

comments.text:
Some states have different laws about payment for services using MV insurance etc, so check that first

Otherwise, you can still so your normal practice for cash pay and be paid at time of service.

If you decide to enter into a payment agreement with their attorney, then make sure you have a letter of protection on file. You likely won't be paid until the case settles and that can take a few months to a few years. In some cases they will pay out of a "fund", but it depends on the state and attorney. Also, most attorneys will come back and try to negotiate the final payout so you want to make sure your paperwork is solid so that you don't end up having to accept a fraction of what is owed. It is possible to build in "interest" to the cost because it won't be paid at time of service, but you also have to make sure you can sustain without being paid for an undisclosed amount of time. I've had some settle in a matter of months and others that have taken more than a year. Ultimately, if the bill isn't paid, it falls on the patient at the end of the day. So keep that in mind as well.
You can stay straight cash if u want.  You can bill PIP until it is exhausted then pivot to cash.  Or wait for settlement (not recommended)

post_text: Geriatric PTs- what services are you offering to your patients that are not covered by Medicare to increase revenue/ visit???  One of my 2026 goals is to offer more cash pay services in addition to typical Medicare PT session, looking for inspiration.  Right now the only one I currently offer is dry needling.

comments.text:
I love that you are asking this question. A lot depends on what you or your team really enjoys doing. 

You already know but I generate the extra income we need through media and affiliate income. 

Selling products is usually an easy one to add. With Amazon‚Äôs next day delivery on a lot of items you could easily buy and resell stuff like little pedal exercisers, walking pads, etc. 

Other services like taking your client out of the house, go to a game, go to the park, go run some errands. As long as you are out of the house it is not a covered service. 

We had a PTA who would travel with patients on cruises. This one is a bit more extreme but he got the free trip and set hours that he was ‚Äúon duty.‚Äù He was paid for that time and could do what he wanted the rest of the time. I could see this working for flights as well.

post_text:
I‚Äôve never understood the appeal of the phrase **‚Äúmove fast and break things.‚Äù** 
It started in the early tech world ‚Äî a rallying cry for startups to grow at all costs, push updates without fully thinking them through, and worry about the consequences later.

Today, it shows up everywhere: in social media posts from ‚Äútalking heads,‚Äù business influencers, and techies who love to preach speed over substance. 

Because when someone proudly uses this phrase, what they‚Äôre really admitting is:
* **They don‚Äôt fully know what they‚Äôre doing.** Breaking things is not innovation; it‚Äôs inexperience masquerading as boldness.
* **The adults in the room to clean up the mess.** Someone else always pays the price for their shortcuts.
* **It‚Äôs fundamentally selfish.** It prioritizes ego, speed, and bravado over responsibility and long-term consequences.

And here‚Äôs the reality: **our profession is not tech.**
Healthcare isn‚Äôt an app you patch later.
Patients aren‚Äôt beta testers.
Care plans and business models should not be ‚Äúlaunched broken‚Äù with the hope of fixing them down the road.

In physical therapy ‚Äî and in healthcare as a whole ‚Äî we don‚Äôt get the luxury of breaking things to see what happens. Our work requires **precision, intention, and accountability**, not recklessness dressed up as innovation.

That‚Äôs why we apply **great caution** with companies, vendors, and even therapists who lean on this mindset. It‚Äôs a red flag. Healthcare demands a higher standard ‚Äî one grounded in expertise, safety, and responsibility.

Real progress doesn‚Äôt come from breaking things.
It comes from **building carefully, thoughtfully, and with respect for the people who trust us with their health.**

Post created by AI (Actual Intelligence)

I don't disagree when it comes to treatment and quality of care but for figuring out your niche / unique offering as a clinic, I'm not sure I necessarily agree. I feel if you ask most successful clinic owners if they knew what they were doing their first couple of years of business they'd say they had no clue. 

As far as patients being "beta testers" though I agree 100% or at the very least if they are they need to know this upfront (and most likely receive a discount since they are willing to take the risk).

When you started out on your own, what did you do for personal health insurance? I‚Äôm currently in school based and hired directly so I have great insurance and my husband‚Äôs is meh ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 

Curious as to what y‚Äôall have found! We are currently 2 adults and 1 child in Illinois at the moment. Currently paying somewhere between $350 and $375 per pay period (2x/month) for the family.

comments.text:
Something to keep in mind (I did a lot of digging into this)‚Ä¶

If you do a plan through ACA or a private insurance company you can often pay the premiums through your business. You‚Äôll need to check with your accountant and it‚Äôs based on the type of business structure. My understanding is you can‚Äôt do that with healthshares because they aren‚Äôt in the right tax category for the accounting forms. Also, they are not guaranteeing care. It can be a gamble for people with pre-existing conditions (protected under ACA - for now).

It‚Äôs important to look into all of it because each person will have different needs, risk profiles, risk aversions etc. If one is young with no pre-existing conditions and is cool with paying a low premium out of pocket - health shares can be great. 

It will also depend on your income. If you can get subsidies through ACA - it‚Äôs a great option. 

High earners face a lot of challenges with this.

If you do a plan through ACA or a private insurance company you can often pay the premiums through your business. You‚Äôll need to check with your accountant and it‚Äôs based on the type of business structure. My understanding is you can‚Äôt do that with healthshares because they aren‚Äôt in the right tax category for the accounting forms. Also, they are not guaranteeing care. It can be a gamble for people with pre-existing conditions (protected under ACA - for now).

It‚Äôs important to look into all of it because each person will have different needs, risk profiles, risk aversions etc. If one is young with no pre-existing conditions and is cool with paying a low premium out of pocket - health shares can be great. 

It will also depend on your income. If you can get subsidies through ACA - it‚Äôs a great option. 

High earners face a lot of challenges with this.

post_text:
Private practice while working for insurance based company. 

I have a cash-based private practice that I work weekends and some evenings. I still have a full time job at a larger insurance based practice. This week at my full-time job, I evaluated a patient and scheduled follow ups.  I spoke her her the next day and she told me that she was surprised that her eval was $400.  She was never told the expected outcome of pocket by the authorizations team or her insurance. She found out she is covered for PT at 50% AFTER a $3500 deductible.  So each session will likely be $400 which is not doable for her and she said she will have to cancel all follow ups.  I suggested that she could find a practice that is cash based so that she can continue treatment at an affordable rate. She asked me for suggestions multiple times.  I told her she could probably Google pelvic PTs. I am the only one in the town I work in. The closest town (which is also across state lines) is about 45 minutes -1 hour away.  That is where I live and have a cash based practice.  I don‚Äôt want to conflict of interest or look like I am soliciting.  So should I just tell her to Google and let her figure it out‚Ä¶ Or since she asked for specific practices, provide her with a list of several to choose from and include my practice on the list?  Again, she decided to cancel with my insurance based company due to the high cost. Then specifically asked for recommendations in the next closest town which is about an hour away and in a different state. So are there any issues with giving her options including my cash-based practice?  At this point, my practice is not public knowledge with my current employer since I practice in a different state an hour away and do not directly compete since I am cash-based. Advice?

comments.text:
I think it is definitely a conflict of interest to take a client from your employer and move them to your cash based practice. 

I never ever see a client privately who i met at my employer without disclosing that to (and getting permission from) my employer. 

Agree that $400 for a PT visit is insane. 

If you can't disclose to your employer, I would probably just stop communicating with her. 

If she finds you on Google and reaches out to your personal contact then you have to decide if you feel ethically OK to accept her as a client.
I would provide her a list but not include my own as it‚Äôs a conflict of interest. If she finds you on her own then no problem.

I usually offer a slight discount for the sibling(s)

post_text:
Does workers comp work the same as no fault? What should I know before I take a workers comp case? How much does it usually pay?

Thank you

comments.text: I used to make about $220 a visit for work comp. The biggest thing to make sure is that you have preauth. Do NOT take someone‚Äôs word that it is covered. Usually, they would approve the eval and then more visits after the eval. Usually, 10 visits at a time is what they did for me. This was 7 years ago. Occasionally, a wc adjuster would call to ask if I thought the patient was malingering or just full faking. I didn‚Äôt have anyone I ever thought was completely faking, but I would always write much better bites and put exactly what they said and did.  I do the same with liability claims. I mostly had no problem with wc and have thought about taking it along with my self pay clients.
What in the usa are you?

post_text:
Does anyone here charge a flat fee ‚Äúextra‚Äù for same day and/or holiday appointments? I never have, but I have one patient specifically who always contacts me asking for an appt that same day, often within hours. Sometimes I can, and I do. Sometimes I do not have childcare set up since it wasnt a prior made appt, and I turn down the appt that day. Now, if I can make it work, I do and always have, but the incentive of extra charge if requesting an appt within hours seems appealing but also maybe not haha. 

What about holidays?

Thanks

comments.text:
Charge extra for holidays/vacations and out of hours visits. 
I‚Äôve lived by this and some clients don‚Äôt care and some do. They schedule to what fits their needs. I‚Äôm also a strong believer in ‚Äúno‚Äù is a full sentence. You can treat them if you want or not without explanation. 

Your practice- you do it how it best suits you. 

PS- did the holiday rates last year for PT visits because I had intended  to take off for the holiday. Got inundated with calls for visits. Upped my rates and no one complained. So guess whose rates went up üòâ sometimes it‚Äôs a nice way to see if a price increase will be accepted by your clientele. 

Good luck!
For holidays and outside of normal hours makes sense‚Ä¶ same day I don‚Äôt. I just get excited I can fill a gap

post_text: Hi all‚Äî do any therapists here do PT or OT services on a ‚Äúmonthly subscription‚Äù schedule (vs charging per session or a packaged plan)? I have encountered MDs who are offering their primary care services on monthly subscriptions, and for a lot of patients, this is more affordable than paying insurance. Just looking to hear what people are doing in their business models to stay away from dealing with insurance. If you can describe briefly how you structure your services and why you chose that approach vs another, that would be very helpful. Thanks in advance! üôÇ

comments.text: Yes!

It's hard to do monthly like PCPs do unless you are offering wellness and prevention or you limit it to 3 months or so. Your also have take sure you aren't doing 8 visits a month for the rate a PCP would charge. PCPs are getting them for an entire year and our care is more episodic so unless you are going to offer other things or make it a wellness service, you will be losing out. PCPs charge $150-$200/month for unlimited access and visits. You need high volume to make that model work and typically our panel size doesn't justify unlimited access for that cheap a month.

full_thread_text:

Just looking to hear what people are doing in their business models to stay away from dealing with insurance. If you can describe briefly how you structure your services and why you chose that approach vs another, that would be very helpful. Thanks in advance! üôÇ

COMMENT 1: Yes!

COMMENT 2: It's hard to do monthly like PCPs do unless you are offering wellness and prevention or you limit it to 3 months or so. Your also have take sure you aren't doing 8 visits a month for the rate a PCP would charge. Am I crazy? Excited but kinda worried that when all work out, patients will be pouring. When I gave up the 9-5 snf, I enjoyed the freedom, family, vacays and life with a non rehab business as I ‚Äúput things together.‚Äù with goals of online and private pay therapy. Basically semi-retired.

post_text:
Looking for advice and suggestions. 
I own a small cash based OT practice in FL. 
With my practice I do private sessions in homes and group based sessions in the community. From adult to older adult. I recently stopped all of my PRN work to dive full time in my practice. Life has hit a little harder than expected, I am in a place where I need to find a side position to make additional income. Any ideas of what side hustles to do? I am torn between doing another OT position or just something completely different on the side to give my brain an OT break due to the stress of starting an OT company. I am feeling extremely defeated. Also, for those that have a cash based practice how long did it take to really get going?

comments.text: Taking Medicare would definitely open a larger client population for you. People often don't realize the time required to build community connections and establish a reputation. OT is harder than PT for sure. I am happy to chat with you about options to build your practice.

I manage my husband‚Äôs mobile PT practice and enrolling with Medicare made a huge difference (only traditional Medicare and OON with advantage plans), he still has cash patients and charges his rate and quite often Medicare patients become his private pay patients after discharge from Medicare services if they want to continue wellness. I myself  trade futures in the market. I feel it‚Äôs the best skill in the world but the hardest one to learn but if you master it you are golden. I only trade 1-3 hours in the evening, last night was great, I made more than double on 2 trades than working 10 hour shift as charge nurse with weekend differential lol. But it‚Äôs a skill like any other that you need to learn. Affiliate marketing, selling life insurance on the side, digital products are some other side hustles that our healthcare friends do for extra income. Feel free to DM me.

I myself  trade futures in the market. I feel it‚Äôs the best skill in the world but the hardest one to learn but if you master it you are golden. I only trade 1-3 hours in the evening, last night was great, I made more than double on 2 trades than working 10 hour shift as charge nurse with weekend differential lol. But it‚Äôs a skill like any other that you need to learn. Affiliate marketing, selling life insurance on the side, digital products are some other side hustles that our healthcare friends do for extra income. Feel free to DM me.

post_text:
I am starting my llc, and will be a 1099 employee/sole PT at a boutique personal training gym. I have zero experience with owning my own business, and feel like I have a steep learning curve as I'm still a fairly new PT, with my only experience being in hospital OP. 

The owner of the gym is an ATC, and I am happy with our agreement, where I am not leasing my space for a set rate, but we have a 30/70 split for each patient I see. With having access to a beautiful and well equipped gym, treatment room, showers, marketing assistance, etc, I am happy with taking home 70%. This will also be 100% cash based. 

Someone mentioned that fee splitting may be an issue, but I'm not seeing anything specific to cash based services. This isn't a kickback situation from physician referrals, and I am not dealing with Medicare. 

Am I missing anything? I don't know what I don't know at this point.

comments.text: I know you are happy taking 70%, but want to throw out some numbers for you to think about. If you make $10,000 a month, you owe the gym owner $3000 which is a lot of money for your rent set up. You take $7000 but also need to pay taxes out of that $7000. I would run some more numbers to make sure you are ok with that income
Fee splitting allows them access to your books.  Have u thought of a flat fee per patient?

post_text: For anyone that has worked on personal injury/lien cases, what has been your experience? I have always stayed away from it because of the long wait to get paid but wasn‚Äôt sure just how long you usually have to wait?

comments.text:
I work with these. I ask for the patient to pay me at the time of service then they get reimbursed later. 

I charge $130/hr to prepare paperwork for litigation, meaning printing and mailing the paperwork and documentation. I usually wait until the lawyers ask me for this. I am upfront about this charge when I first take clients. For the first time, I had lawyers only want to pay me $50 for that service. I had to argue with them about how my rate is lower the state statue for that fee. However, our justifications are valuable and I put a lot of effort into my letters and documentation to verify justification for services. 

If I did not get paid at the time of service I would add an interest charge to the money you have to wait for. That way it‚Äôs worth it for you. I still never do this‚Ä¶ I‚Äôd rather be paid at time of service. Just to avoid issues.
I have the client pay at the time of service. They get reimbursed later. I charge $130/hr to prepare documents for court when the lawyers tell me to.

full_thread_text:
POST: For anyone that has worked on personal injury/lien cases, what has been your experience? I have always stayed away from it because of the long wait to get paid but wasn‚Äôt sure just how long you usually have to wait?

COMMENT 1: I work with these. I ask for the patient to pay me at the time of service then they get reimbursed later. 

I charge $130/hr to prepare paperwork for litigation, meaning printing and mailing the paperwork and documentation. I usually wait until the lawyers ask me for this. I am upfront about this charge when I first take clients. For the first time, I had lawyers only want to pay me $50 for that service. I had to argue with them about how my rate is lower the state statue for that fee. However, our justifications are valuable and I put a lot of effort into my letters and documentation to verify justification for services. 

If I did not get paid at the time of service I would add an interest charge to the money you have to wait for. That way it‚Äôs worth it for you. I still never do this‚Ä¶ I‚Äôd rather be paid at time of service. Just to avoid issues.

COMMENT 2: I have the client pay at the time of service. They get reimbursed later. I charge $130/hr to prepare documents for court when the lawyers tell me to.

Hey everyone, have a unique situation where a client of mine is looking to have me travel with them for a good chunk of the year. Doing a mix of PT / personal training / health and wellness. Totally negotiable and everything is up in the air. Any advice on how to proceed with this? I typically charge him $150 for in-home sessions. 

My first thought was to use an annual fee that would encompass a reasonable amount of sessions at a higher than normal rate, and have stipulations to include reimbursement for travel costs.

comments.text: I would think a daily rate for each day you‚Äôre gone (including travel days), then an additional fee for each service during their trip, and full payment of all travel costs, including meals, transportation, and lodging.
Exactly, John. Have an annual fee with the stipulations you mentioned üëåüëå

full_thread_text:
POST: Hey everyone, have a unique situation where a client of mine is looking to have me travel with them for a good chunk of the year. Doing a mix of PT / personal training / health and wellness. Totally negotiable and everything is up in the air. Any advice on how to proceed with this? I typically charge him $150 for in-home sessions. 

My first thought was to use an annual fee that would encompass a reasonable amount of sessions at a higher than normal rate, and have stipulations to include reimbursement for travel costs.

post_text: Explain to me like I‚Äôm a PT toddler‚Ä¶in a Cash Based Wellness setting can Medicare patients cash pay? How do I document  to reflect Wellness only?

comments.text:
I feel like everyone is over complicating this. The OP said cash based welless practice....

It depends on what services you are offering this person in your "cash based wellness setting". If it is truly a service like personal training or fitness related and doesn't fall under physical therapy, then absolutely you can accept cash. 

Now you can't just rename it wellness if it truly is a physical therapy service, that requires the care of a physical therapist and you are treating a specific diagnosis.

But if they're seeing you just simply to get stronger, get in better shape, lose weight, etc and it doesn't fall under physical therapy, you can charge cash.

I hope that helps a bit!

‚ÄúPatient is able to perform independent ADLs and self care, but is seeking additional interventions to improve tolerance and skill for recreational activities‚Äù 

Can really write whatever you want. Have a justifiable reason and get an ABN and you‚Äôre fine. Medicare is not going to come after you for saving them money, you‚Äôre just justifying receiving cash in case a patient tries to get reimbursed on the back end later. If you make sure they know it‚Äôs not covered you are unlikely to ever have an issue.

full_thread_text:
POST: Explain to me like I‚Äôm a PT toddler‚Ä¶in a Cash Based Wellness setting can Medicare patients cash pay? How do I document  to reflect Wellness only?

COMMENT 1: I feel like everyone is over complicating this. The OP said cash based welless practice....

It depends on what services you are offering this person in your "cash based wellness setting". If it is truly a service like personal training or fitness related and doesn't fall under physical therapy, then absolutely you can accept cash. 

Now you can't just rename it wellness if it truly is a physical therapy service, that requires the care of a physical therapist and you are treating a specific diagnosis.

But if they're seeing you just simply to get stronger, get in better shape, lose weight, etc and it doesn't fall under physical therapy, you can charge cash.

I hope that helps a bit!

COMMENT 2: ‚ÄúPatient is able to perform independent ADLs and self care, but is seeking additional interventions to improve tolerance and skill for recreational activities‚Äù 

Can really write whatever you want. Have a justifiable reason and get an ABN and you‚Äôre fine. Medicare is not going to come after you for saving them money, you‚Äôre just justifying receiving cash in case a patient tries to get reimbursed on the back end later. If you make sure they know it‚Äôs not covered you are unlikely to ever have an issue.

I‚Äôm seeing a new patient who is in-network, but they have a high deductible. Since the deductible hasn‚Äôt been met, the patient will likely be responsible for the full amount. Although I‚Äôd like to charge them as self-pay, I understand that because I‚Äôm in-network, I must bill insurance according to the contracted rates.

For a typical session involving 4‚Äì5 units, how should I bill this appropriately?
This is only my third patient as a new practice owner, so I want to make sure I‚Äôm doing everything correctly.

comments.text: You should have a fee schedule for what you charge per unit for each CPT codes. The amount they pay would be based upon your fee schedule and the units billed.

Ah ok, so their deductible hasn't been met, the clinic will charge based on their insurance carrier, that goes towards their deductible, say for instance $160 for the first visit and $130-70 the 2nd, until the deductible is met, then the co-pay kicks in.

post_text: I have a home office where I specialize in the TMJ and Myofunctional therapy. I was contacted by a new dentist asking me if I could come work in their office a few days per month, and of course they would take a cut of my pay.  This is not something I‚Äôm interested in doing, but i could definitely use their referrals. Is there any compromise you suggest doing in this situation ?

comments.text: Nice kick back arrangement he is looking for.

Raise your rate by the exact amount he wants for his cut. Tell any patient that asks that the increased fee is to cover the rent.  You walk away with the same.

The referral part is tricky because it‚Äôs a med pro. Technically him taking a cut of any referred business is a violation of stark law, but POPTs exist sooo.

My guess is you will get many of these as space becomes more expensive. Choose a number that makes you feel good about it and tell him to take a walk if he negotiates. Sounds like he‚Äôs not a big referral source currently? There are a million dentists

Mobile practice here, first time coming across this, client lives downtown and therapist has to pay $2.50/hr for parking. 1 hr sessions with walking time of a 5-10 min total to the apartment.
What would you guys do? Eat the $3-5/visit and reimburse the therapist for it. The client is likely to do 2-4 visits a week with us between a few disciplines for now or add $3-5 to every visit

comments.text: If I practiced by myself and had high profit margins, then I would eat the cost. If I had low margins, lots of employees, already have a high volume of patients and can easily afford to not see this patient, I would charge them the parking.
If you‚Äôre concerned about $5 parking, profit margins are too low. Company should reimburse this if you work for someone or if you‚Äôre cash you‚Äôre not charging enough.

post_text:
Hi all,

I am in the process of starting a concierge cash mobile PT business. I know pricing on visits is a common question and I keep going back and forth on what to charge. My plan is to offer packages with the main one being basically unlimited visits until they meet their goals for $5000. Obviously there is going to be some stipulations for that to avoid people taking advantage. Otherwise, the goal will be to charge about $285 a visit. I am located in the Prescott/Prescott Valley area in Arizona. 

Looking for thoughts and opinions on this and what other mobile cash PTs have charged.

comments.text:
We are hybrid so I have two styles 

Cash only 
I‚Äôve done this. We do 10k for the year. Unlimited treatment plans 

2k per month unlimited or 5500 for 3 months. For say like ACL R or TKA type thing. 

Also have an annual membership for the insurance side 
1500/year  annual wellness stuff plus discounts on cash services
4500/year  basically large discounts on cash services. Fitness. Exercise programming nutrition shockwaves ultrasound imaging etc 

We do have a B&M so that helps with more services to offer vs just the mobile providers.

To add. We‚Äôve never had a single membership person overuse their membership. They actually understood the value and probably used it much less than say your typical insurance patient who expects the moon

Love seeing you building a concierge PT model that puts patients first! Curious what specific stipulations you‚Äôre including to protect your time with the $5K unlimited package. Also, what are other mobile cash PTs in the area charging per hour?

We are trying to find a balance between INN insurance based visits and our people that come every 4-8 weeks for a check in. 
My husband just went in network after doing strictly cash based and we are trying to figure out a model to accommodate both types without problems. (Legally or having complaints/drop offs from clients.) He will have a PTA to help with insurance visits.
He does training as well so I know there‚Äôs a good line there, but for a few he only needs to see them every now and then (usually TMJ, neck or athletes with tweaks)

COMMENT 1: How about one patients graduate from physical therapy? They can sign up for a wellness plan. They can come every two weeks or once a month for self-pay appointment

COMMENT 2: See if your EMR has remote. Therapeutic monitoring

Does anyone add interest on to unpaid invoices after a certain period of time? I usually only use invoices if someone forgot their credit card or wants to wait a few days to pay, but am wondering if after 2 weeks or so a small interest rate should be added. Anyone doing this?
Any legal ramifications? Bad idea? Would need to include this in intake forms.

comments.text:

2) 2 weeks seems quick but that‚Äôs just me I operate on Net 30 invoices. 

3) that fee needs to be clearly stated and signed off on by the pt. 

4) id prob brand it more as a ‚Äúlate fee‚Äù rather than ‚Äúinterest payment‚Äù patients don‚Äôt want to unknowingly enter into financing agreements. 

5) why not require a card on file?

Hey question for PT‚Äòs in Texas! I‚Äôve recently had a pediatric patient that is very committed ask for a discounted rate due to financial situation. I want to make sure I‚Äôve covered my butt, but I‚Äôm happy to do it for this family. 

Has anyone had this circumstance? Is it better to do a sliding scale or do a Package deal, which I‚Äôve never wanted to do otherwise and dont plan to do otherwise? 

Also, I‚Äôve seen advice for submitting super bills to still keep my original rate per session on there  even though I‚Äôm giving a discounted rate for this circumstance. ÔøºBut is this allowed? Any advice would be welcome. Thank you so much! Ôøº

comments.text: Charge however you want. Typically if its a financial hardship, they cannot front the cost if a package. Options would be payment plan to pay down balance or just a cheaper rate.  Cannot fudge the superbill, that would be fraud.

post_text: Is anyone willing to share their single visit rate vs package rate and how they went about deciding if packages were a good idea?   Currently I don‚Äôt offer packages but considering it as a way to offer a more affordable option to those who need it.   Thank you!

comments.text: I did primarily packages for about a year and now have switched to $150/session. Honestly has just been better all around with everyone paying the same rate and losing less in discounts all over the place. I do offer paid in full options for anyone who wants nothing to do with Superbills/insurance and just wants to pay in full for 12 sessions. Those are 10% off but I rarely use those now

The rates people are sharing will fluctuate depending on location, specialty, and if mobile/concierge. Consider a sales tactic called price anchoring where you have a significantly higher single session rate and packages that seem like a great discount. This pushes people to get the package, which leads to more money upfront and commitment from the patient's end to complete the POC. Individual sessions can lead to drop off/no show when the patient stops seeing the value or if there isnt an immediate change

post_text:
Is there anyone doing a "cash discount" as in patients paying with literal Benjamin Franklins?

I was discussing with a chiropractor who does this. Their thought is that a cash patient is not triggering the credit card fee, and most of them are not asking for superbills thus saving time. Plus, patients love a discount.

I use Square (losing about $10 per patient) and I use Google Workspace, so I have to manually take time to make superbills.

comments.text: Nope. Just say cash is preferred but multiple payment options are available, then they have no issue paying my full rate. I think many people understand how cash is extra helpful to a biz so they don't mind paying that way, but why short change yourself on decreasing the rate? I don't know the exact process but the interest on square can be used on your taxes too.

Please shop credit card processors. I always recommend going through underwriting with a bank because a) the fees are usually lower and b) they won‚Äôt randomly freeze your account if you sell multiple packages or land a big client (because they have already vetted you). Happened to 3 colleagues

Also cash discount screams tax evasion

post_text:
question
What do you guys do when an obviously rich patient is asking for a 50$ discount on your cash prices. I work in NYC and I think I charge pretty low (150$) and they want aquatic therapy with the pool in their temporary building which frankly I‚Äôd charge 180$ for. I don‚Äôt take their insurance. I‚Äôm not sure how to put my foot down about prices or try to come to a compromise.

comments.text: You respectfully tell them, "I dedicate a lot of time, effort, and resources to provide premium PT experience."  If they still want the the discount  tell them to kick rocks.
That‚Äôs one of the reasons they are rich. Never be ashamed to ask for a deal as a consumer. However, always be ready to politely explain why you don‚Äôt offer deals.

post_text:
Hi everyone,
I‚Äôm currently in early discussions with an assisted living facility that‚Äôs offering to rent me a space for $570/month. They also mentioned potentially taking a percentage of concierge service revenue.

At this point, there‚Äôs no formal contract on either side. Before I commit, I‚Äôd love to hear from those who‚Äôve done something similar:
 ‚Ä¢ What are fair or negotiable terms in these types of agreements?
 ‚Ä¢ Any red flags I should watch out for?
 ‚Ä¢ Would you suggest a flat rent only, percentage only, or a hybrid?
 ‚Ä¢ How do you structure services (Medicare Part B, private pay, wellness/stretch programs, etc.) in this kind of setting?
 ‚Ä¢ Any tips for ensuring the agreement is sustainable and protects my business interests?

Your input would be hugely appreciated. Thank you in advance!

comments.text: I wouldn‚Äôt get involved with anyone who wants to be in your books and taking a percentage. The flat rate is very reasonable, if you have your own space.
Flat rate and a percentage?  No way.  Per person charge or hourly rate most preferred.  When business picks up, a monthly rate may be best.  Keep them out of your books...

post_text: I‚Äôm a mobile provider but going to start seeing a few clients out of a gym. How much do you pay the gym owner per hour or per client that you are there? I‚Äôm located in southern NH. Thanks for your thoughts!

comments.text: Many will say to NOT do a percentage, because as you get busier then you will continue to pay more - but I think a percentage with an agreed upon max or cap is a smart move.

I‚Äôm in Concord and we agreed upon a percentage up to a max of $500/month. I just did the math of $500/160 (full-time hours for a month) to get an hourly rate of $3.12. However, I consider 20 patients/week full for me so I doubled it to $6.24/hour.

full_thread_text:
POST: I‚Äôm a mobile provider but going to start seeing a few clients out of a gym. How much do you pay the gym owner per hour or per client that you are there? I‚Äôm located in southern NH. Thanks for your thoughts!

COMMENT 1: Many will say to NOT do a percentage, because as you get busier then you will continue to pay more - but I think a percentage with an agreed upon max or cap is a smart move.

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôm in Concord and we agreed upon a percentage up to a max of $500/month. I just did the math of $500/160 (full-time hours for a month) to get an hourly rate of $3.12. However, I consider 20 patients/week full for me so I doubled it to $6.24/hour.

post_text:
I have a brick and mortar practice AND work a part time job. 

I have enough private patients on my waitlist to quit my job now, but I‚Äôd be working more and making less than working my job (I‚Äôve been doing it 20 years and am very well compensated).

To make sense I‚Äôd have to charge $157 vs the $135 I charge now. 

I am thinking of raising the price to $160 to all new patients (the current ones will eventually phase out), and wait until I am fully booked at new price before I quit. (Mainly because I am on the scared side, and think I will be too scared of changing prices and not having a caseload AFTER leaving my ‚Äúsafety‚Äù. 

At the same time I see everyone on my waitlist and feel I need to get out and see them. 

Thoughts? 

Ps: I did quit my job once already a year ago, to realize insurance pays would not meet my financial needs and have to return to my job to be able to ease off insurances.

comments.text: Or‚Ä¶you could be treating half as much and making double (still working a lot at first for sure though) Not sure where you are but here around Boston most clinics are charging around 250/hr including my practice. Unless you‚Äôre somewhere that cost of living is extremely cheap I would put my money on it the local plumber might be charging more than you right now.

A few questions: 
1.) what made you start your part-time gig? 
2.) how long is your waitlist at present? Time in for eval/visit? 
3.) have you raised prices before? 
4.) is your goal to move completely to your part-time gig and ditch insurance? 
5.) how much more work would you be taking on by making the switch? There‚Äôs a lot of things that can be taken care of through automation of processes that take a lot off your plate. 

These are all questions I ask ppl that I mentor or are on the fence. The initial fear of not having a ‚Äúconsistent‚Äù paycheck is real, but you can end up making more in the end with far greater flexibility. In my area, $157 is far below market value for a cash-pay visit. So I would do a little research and see how your prices compare to other providers in the area. 

Then make your decision üòä

post_text: I had an employer ask me about how someone who is an entry level employee or low wage income worker could access my expertise if I don't accept insurance. For so many reasons, I  never plan on billing insurance or participating. Just curious if any of you do sliding fee scales based on income level? Is it even legal? And how are you  providing access for all clients, not just those with disposable incomes?

comments.text:
I have had people pay for my services with their stimulus checks. 

A woman went and got a job at a daycare after being a stay at home mom for 15+ years. Why? Because her husband refused to pay for her treatment with me. She came back after saving for a few months and paid full with her own money. (I didn‚Äôt just empower her with her health but now she has her own income and confidence to not stay dependent on another human for her well-being.) 

At times, we have to allow people to figure out how they will get what they desire. It allows them to rise above their excuses. 

That is not to say we shouldn‚Äôt discount our services at all. But it would take a lot before someone can convince me why I should earn less so that they can save on their health. 

The same people have the money for tattoos, $400 eyelashes, 100s of $$ of hair styles and highlights, money for beer on weekends, money for all the gadgets and car stuff. 

They need to figure out where they can save or earn more to pay for my expertise. 

I used to have a real difficult time not getting sucked into people‚Äôs sad stories until a coach said ‚Äúwould you take food out of your child‚Äôs mouth to feed someone else? That‚Äôs what you are doing when you don‚Äôt charge what you are worth. You are taking it away from your child.‚Äù That really hit home for me. 

Also, people who pay the full price are the same people who are most compliant and actually get results. In the past, everytime I discounted my services beyond my comfort level, the people didn‚Äôt even put in the work. 

People have to have their skin in the game. What they are willing to pay for soemthing is a direct reflection of how much they value it.

It is not my responsibility to be a financial advisor for my patients. It IS my responsibility to run a sustainable business model so that I am here for years to come and don‚Äôt have close my business because I‚Äôm not profitable. I can help the biggest amount of patients by running a sustainable business model that yes, includes profitability. There are rare instances where I give patients pay-what-you-can visits. Ôøº Ironically, I have had some of those patients I tried to help with discounts not be grateful and no-show to those appointments. Ôøº

post_text:
Looking for assistance with hiring and negotiations! I usually try to avoid anonymous posts to be more personable but I currently have applicants and feel like it's better anonymous. 

I am hiring a PT 1099 (I know this can be controversial). They will be paid per session. If you have contractors or employees that are paid per session... do you have a separate evaluation rate vs treatment rate? Do you aim to pay a certain percentage of what you bring in as a private pay practice?

Also, my treatment sessions are typically an hour. I'm finding it difficult to expand the schedule to accommodate close to 40 hours without feeling like it's going to cause burnout. Taking into consideration have a lunch in the middle of the day, this would either be 5 days x 7 clients (35 hours) or 4 days x 9 clients (36 hours). I know that 1099 ‚Äúmake their own schedule‚Äù but their hope is to achieve full time Any recommendations on navigating this?

Thank you  for your advice!

comments.text: I pay the same because I don't want to incentivize less treatments to make room for evals

Just FYI what you are describing does not sound like a 1099 situation‚ÄîI would very carefully look up your DOL regulations. I got audited and had a OT (I am PT) who worked about about 10 hours for me and I was fined for not classifying them correctly‚Äîthis was a very limited need for a single client.

post_text:
What would you charge for exercise programming? 

I also see personal training clients (typically non-medicare or Medicare patients who are well beyond therapy discharge)  and I'm trying to navigate how much to charge. I'm seeing a client today for an assessment and then he would like exercise programming for a few months. I will likely program a month at a time with the opportunity for weekly check-ins, and for him to message me with his feedback on the workouts, etc.

I'm really stumped with how much to charge. I know there are personal trainers out there charging $500 a month for a service like this.  

 I'm still struggling with this as I continue to navigate into the cash only space.  I've clearly been conditioned by our crappy health care system to accept crap pay for my skill set and trying to break free of that mindset. 

Any input appreciated!

comments.text: Depends on your time with them. Whether it is exercise or teaching won‚Äôt matter. . Go by 30 min intervals

I would echo all the above. What are YOU worth and what would make YOU happy from a charge standpoint? Then, estimate approximate hours to serve the individual and you're set. 

Don't look at anyone else or feel like you missed out on potential pay/feel like you're charging too much. Personally, I feel as though I am worth $200-$250 per hour. 

Sometimes I feel like it's a lot until I see others charge $350-$500. I got $250 because that's what my lawyer charges. They are the best in their field and so am I.

 I'm still struggling with this as I continue to navigate into the cash only space.  I've clearly been conditioned by our crappy health care system to accept crap pay for my skill set and trying to break free of that mindset. 

Any input appreciated!

Sometimes I feel like it's a lot until I see others charge $350-$500. I got $250 because that's what my lawyer charges. They are the best in their field and so am I.

I would love to hear from cash therapists in small rural towns NOT in California or states with higher income.

I am in rural SC, town with no more than 30k people, 1.5hs from bigger city, average household income of $55k.

I run a great successful insurance practice with 1-1 individual high level care, high success rate, but can only see so many a week and I can make same income working less doing home health. 

I am basically working more and making less just so I can choose my own PTO. 

Pelvic floor - I‚Äôd need to charge at least 162 to make budget 

Ps if you are insurance based or feel cash based don‚Äôt work in small areas this is not the post. I want to see who made and succeeded

comments.text: There are TONS of cash practices in rural areas that thrive. I‚Äôm still building my practice, but I was able to replace my income from both my full-time insurance job and my PRN acute care job by seeing 8 patients/week. If you‚Äôre thinking of starting your own cash based pelvic practice, recommend Pelvic PT/OT Entrepreneurs group and looking into the Pelvic PT Rising mentorship programs because they are a total game changer.

Looking for advice from anyone here that has or is currently renting space inside a gym. 
I‚Äôm working on writing up a contract with a local gymnastics gym after treating some of their athletes. Gym is about 30,000 sq ft with about 500 members and 20 coaches. There‚Äôs no private space/office so I‚Äôd be setup either near the weights or in an open mat area with roughly 100-150 sq ft. It‚Äôs very flexible and seems like I can make what I want of it, so thinking of starting at 1-2 days per week for 4-6 hours and see how things evolve. post_text: Does anyone have a yearly membership or retainer program? I‚Äôd love to chat and see what that looks like. I have a client that calls me when she travels and gets dizzy. She gets recurrent dizzy spells and needs help navigating her symptoms. I also see her in person when she is in state. So between phone calls, virtual sessions, check ins, home exercises, and in person sessions I‚Äôm wondering if I could put some kind of package together that she could put me on retainer( and what people are charging for something like this)

comments.text: A membership program has been on my to do list 1.5 years. Would love to hear what others are doing.

I've spoken with several MDs, Chiros, and PTs who have done this. The over arching theme has been that you make money from having a lot of members and not by charging a lot. You still have to charge a good amount. $100/month is $1200 a year and if you have 100 members, it adds up. 
I have not started a program yet though so don't follow my advice. I am still running numbers so that I don't over promise and under deliver or get bogged down.

post_text:
Hi Everyone,

I will be working with multiple athletes (20+) starting next year and was wondering how you go about recommending certain things for them to get? For example, KT tape, resistance bands, stretching strap, etc. 

I came up with 2 options:
1. Create an Amazon "page" of my recommended items that I can then refer my client to go to.
2. Purchase everything on my own and sell it in-person when I see my client. Less ideal because I have to deal with inventory, but it is possible to "charge" more for this option since I am providing a convenience. 
3. This option was brought up by family: drop shipping.

Please let me know what any of you do when it comes to these types of recommendations! TIA!

comments.text: The thing is Amazon gets it to you so fast that I wouldn‚Äôt carry inventory and I would use option 2. Double the price of everything and just sell it in a bundle.

FUNCTIONAL CAPACITY EXAM (FCE) Question:

Does anyone here do FCEs? Looking for a form (I've done them at a previous employer & prefer not to have to re-create!) and  a ballpark of cost.

comments.text: We use WebFCE. It‚Äôs all neatly laid out for you and generates a nice form letter and everything. I‚Äôm not sure of the cost of use for the software since I don‚Äôt own the clinic, but I know we charge $1200 for a 4 hour FCE and I think $200 for a basic 1 hour pre-work screen. Discounts for cash pay clients and some contracted rates with workers comp and lawyers offices. But our price starts at $1200. I‚Äôm in Florida if that makes a difference for you.

post_text: I have an independent contractor who will be doing home visits only.  I've incorporated an increased rate per hour to reflect the travel charge.  She will get a percentage of what is charged.  Obviously her price per unit or charge code is higher than mine in clinic.  Can I ethically do that or do I need to charge the same, and then add a travel fee?  I offer people superbills, is it unethical to charge more per unit (technically) bc of it's in the home or does that matter?  Hope this is clear, thank you!

comments.text:
So, if Medicare, you cannot charge a travel fee.

 If private pay, I'd bake a travel fee into my session cost say
In clinic is $x/hr
In home is $x+20/hr 

For superbills, you could have your fee schedule set for the more expensive rate, and give a facility discount for those in clinic. I know "time of service" discounts are often used for cash rates that are lower than insurance billed rates.

If she's a 1099, she can write off the mileage herself on her taxes, so I would stick with a higher percentage of net. For example, if MCR reimburses $100 for a daily visit you could pay her $65-70/visit. Obviously, you need to cover all your expenses. But, once those are covered, then you can decide how aggressive you want to do it. I think Luna pays $65-70/visit (1099) in my area. I would also make sure she is educated on the differences in reimbursements for the various codes so she can charge appropriately. Let her see how those differences affect the bottom line, and ultimately her bottom line.

full_thread_text:

I offer people superbills, is it unethical to charge more per unit (technically) bc of it's in the home or does that matter?  Hope this is clear, thank you!

COMMENT 1: So, if Medicare, you cannot charge a travel fee.

 If private pay, I'd bake a travel fee into my session cost say

For superbills, you could have your fee schedule set for the more expensive rate, and give a facility discount for those in clinic. I know "time of service" discounts are often used for cash rates that are lower than insurance billed rates.

I would also make sure she is educated on the differences in reimbursements for the various codes so she can charge appropriately. Let her see how those differences affect the bottom line, and ultimately her bottom line.

post_text:
For those who are doing mobile PT and/or pelvic health PT and have hired other PTs, how/what do you pay your therapists? Hourly/salary/rate? 
(In Texas)

comments.text:
I hired a pelvic floor PT (in my brick and mortar clinic) and she has a commission rate - so base pay is one rate and that‚Äôs for any non-patient / non-revenue time like consults, documentation, marketing etc and then she gets a commission rate per service for times when she‚Äôs bringing in revenue (evals, treatment sessions). 

I consulted with an employment attorney to make sure that was legal and allowed, and my employee and I agreed on a base rate. 

So for instance, if she works an 8 hour day I pay her 8 hours at the base rate and if she sees 6 patients that day she gets $xx per patient x 6 extra for that day. She earns more when she does patient care, which is what I hired her for. I own a 100% cash based practice, for reference. This gives her more incentive and accountability for converting patients to evals and full POCs - which helps me avoid burn out from having so much pressure to fill her schedule - we both benefit when she‚Äôs fully booked üåüüåü

*also want to note that I‚Äôm hiring again so if anyone in Colorado Springs is interested (or knows of anyone looking for an amazingly supportive place to work‚Ä¶message me )

post_text: I own a small cash-based practice and have hit my break even point (well, I‚Äôm less than 1 treatment session away‚Ä¶).  When it comes to paying myself a salary from my practice, what do I need to know? I don‚Äôt want to hire a payroll service for myself alone.  My business has a dedicated checkbook.  Is it kosher to write myself a check from that checkbook at ‚Äòsaid salary?‚Äô  Or, do I need to follow a more formal process for legality?

comments.text: Yes, you can pay yourself form the checkbook as an Owners Draw. Then connect with your accountant to find out at what point in revenue/profit you need to transition your business structure and drawing as a salary

I was there a year ago. You need to scale to unload yourself. If you don‚Äôt you‚Äôll be stuck until you quit. Virtual assistants are where it‚Äôs at. I have 6 that work for me full time for the price of 1 in person employee. It‚Äôs pretty amazing.

full_thread_text:
POST: I own a small cash-based practice and have hit my break even point (well, I‚Äôm less than 1 treatment session away‚Ä¶).  When it comes to paying myself a salary from my practice, what do I need to know? I don‚Äôt want to hire a payroll service for myself alone.  My business has a dedicated checkbook.  Is it kosher to write myself a check from that checkbook at ‚Äòsaid salary?‚Äô  Or, do I need to follow a more formal process for legality?

COMMENT 1: Yes, you can pay yourself form the checkbook as an Owners Draw. Then connect with your accountant to find out at what point in revenue/profit you need to transition your business structure and drawing as a salary

COMMENT 2: I was there a year ago. You need to scale to unload yourself. If you don‚Äôt you‚Äôll be stuck until you quit. Virtual assistants are where it‚Äôs at. I have 6 that work for me full time for the price of 1 in person employee. It‚Äôs pretty amazing.

post_text:
I'm starting to think about a small price increase at the beginning of the year. I hate to do this because I know inflation is hitting everyone hard. January 2025 will be 2 years since I had my first price increase which was drastic because I set my initial prices too low. Now I really just need to account for inflation so I'm thinking $10-15/session.  In 2023, I allowed all current clients to stay under the current pricing which was kind of a pain but worked itself out by March or so. My current eval price is $60 higher than my follow up rate. Hindsight I wouldn't have done this but it made more sense when I was selling packages and offered longer eval times. However, now that all sessions are 1 hour across the board, I'd like to go to one rate. My questions are:

How do you determine by how much to increase?
How would you narrow the gap between the follow up rate and eval? The extra money when I have more evals on my schedule is nice but from a financial planning and goal setting point, it makes more sense to me to have 1 price across the board. 

Would love to hear anyone else's thoughts/experiences.

comments.text: I actually want to increase my eval prices so that they're more expensive than my sessions even though both are one hour long!

I kind decided how much to increase by how horribly uncomfortable it made me to say it out loud, And then said 
Know your worth Queen 
And carried on

post_text: Ok guys I have a situation and I‚Äôm hoping to find someone to help. There is a man in Leominster MA hospital who is on a ventilator and his wife cannot get a PT in to his room to do some strength training with him. In order to get him off the vent he needs a stronger core and his family does not know what to do at this time. Are there any PTs who have a mobile cash pay practice that could go into the hospital and help this man out? Are there companies that contract PTs out for this type of situation? TIA!!!

comments.text: As a PT that works in a hospital and has a mobile business I would say this would not be allowed by the hospital and they are not going to contract you to do it. She needs to work with the therapy staff at the hospital to discuss the options.  There is likely more to the story as to why he is not getting therapy.

I have years of ICU experience, and love mobilizing on vents. I feel like there‚Äôs a lot more to this story. 
What meds is he on? What‚Äôs his diagnosis? Are his intensivists calling for PT? Does this hospital have an early mobilizing and ICU therapy crew? 
That being said I can nearly guarantee you that it wouldn‚Äôt be allowed to do cash pay in a hospital setting. Way too much liability not only for the cash pay PT but also for the hospital itself I would think

Seeking advice. Long story, any advice is appreciated. 11 year PT, home health and snf experience. 

This Coming January I'm going to need to take some fmla to be home with my son who is fighting leukemia (all is going as well, but it's a 2.5 year tx). My wife has to go back to work as a teacher in January to keep her job after taking an extended 1 year leave for our sons treatments. Fortunately, if all goes to plan, I should only have to take 3-4 full months off, then he can start going back to school. I'm in nevada, have my llc, type 1 and 2 npi and have dabbled in cash pay in home private services but home health has kept me more than busy and i havent pursued cash pay much. I'm looking at maybe trying to do some cash pay or considerin what it would take to do cash pay/ insurance hybrid while I'm off on fmla after my wife gets home from work. I live in a semi rural area but live 30-45 min from larger areas. How hard was it for everyone to build up a cash clientele and how hard was it for others to break into the referral/insurance realm? Any suggestions on where to start. I have some ideas but thought ideas from like minded individuals could be beneficial. I would like to just supplement my wife's income initially and return to home health ,but if things took off I'd not be opposed. These are just my initial brainstorming thoughts. I may opt to do a long overdue shoulder labrum repair and use some short term disability as well during that time. Please feel free to ask me any pertinent questions and any advice or good vibes to our little guy is appreciated! Picture of us added for fun at one of the local cancer foundation fundraisers!

comments.text: Good luck, prayers for you and the family üôè

Please forgive me is this is naive. 
You're transitioning from your regular therapy business and pick up a few cash pay clients.

post_text: Just listened to a podcast about a pool company who added a payment calculator to their website and their inbound leads went up by 200%. What do we think about adding a payment calculator to a website for cash pt?

comments.text:
I think the main factor to consider here is that:

People WANT pools. Pools are aspirational in that they‚Äôre a status symbol, provide excitement and entertainment, and can be seen as raising the value of a home potentially.

Sadly, no one WANTS physical therapy. And honestly it would be weird for someone to want physical therapy (in the traditional sense of getting rehab for an injury).

Classic cost vs investment scenario. PT is seen as a cost whereas a pool is seen as an investment. 

Definitely worth giving it a shot but I don‚Äôt think it would drive leads. Just my guess!
I think it works great for an asset type product but prob not service based.

Classic cost vs investment scenario. PT is seen as a cost whereas a pool is seen as an investment.

post_text: Hi everyone - asking a bit of broad question, but I definitely need input. I've been approached to provide PT services for a local home hospice company as an Independent Contractor, and I am interested. They've asked me to send them my rates - including for evaluations, follow-ups, and mileage. I've been a PT (DPT) for 11 years, 6 of which I spent working for a home health and hospice company. I also own an LLC providing mobile/concierge pelvic health privately, so the only comparison I have so far is what I charge for that, which is $145 for 90-minute evaluations and $95 for 60-minute follow ups. The home health co I PRN for pays $110 for a SOC (which I wouldn't do in this hospice setting), $70 for evals, and $60 for follow ups, and I live in South Mississippi. Thanks in advance!

comments.text: I would tell them your rates are higher and then begin negotiations. Will you be a 1099 or are you billing them ?

I don‚Äôt think that your rates are outrageous. Further, I don‚Äôt think that they are out of the ballpark.
It would seem that the worst thing that could happen is they would want to negotiate. 

‚ÄúHere are my rates for the clients I‚Äôm serving in this area presently:‚Äù

If you were going to offer them any sort of discount (if they ask) you might consider it just because you wouldn‚Äôt have to necessarily work as hard for the referrals? I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs necessary, though.

post_text: Are there mobile practices that employ staff on a salary basis rather than pay per visit? I'm currently offering pay per visit but am considering switching to salary to provide more stability. How do you handle productivity, particularly when there are frequent cancellations? And how do you incentivize productivity beyond what's expected for the set salary? I'd really like to hear how others manage this.

comments.text: Yes we do.  We have moved to a salary plus commission model.  So they get their base salary for what we expect a normal caseload with cancellations will be and then they make commission for any sessions completed over and above that number.  When we do annual raises and holiday bonuses this is also factored in.  This incentivizes therapists who want to make more money to fill up their schedule.

üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è We have a base visits per week that they are ‚Äòsalaried‚Äô on and then anything over that, they get an additional bonus per visit over their base. If patients cancel and they are going to fall under their base visits/ week, they let me know and they help out with administrative stuff/marketing/ social media/ etc.

full_thread_text:

post_text: Has anyone worked with a sports team as their PT provider? We‚Äôre currently talking to a semi pro team about this and I‚Äôm not quite sure what to offer. The more flexible you can be, the better.

Most of my guys like 90 min- two hour sessions at two or three days a week. To see a whole team maybe 5 therapists would be needed or less therapists and shorter treatments. The more flexible you can be, the better.

I'm considering to raise my prices in a few weeks. I found most OON clinics near me providing pelvic floor PT  are charging $225 for evaluations and follow ups vary based on packages. However the trend ice seen us $150 for a follow up.  These are brick and mortar clinics. 

I'm a mobile PT and I charge significantly less and I'm embarrassed to say what it is üòÇ. Less than these follow up pricesüò≠. 

I'm not completely sold on having packages as I feel it's hard to always give a number of treatments needed for one to get better. 

I'm wondering for those who raised prices after starting what did you charge before and after. What are some things to take into account? Was it hard to get patients in after the change in pricing?

comments.text: I went from $150 to $250 for self pay mobile visits around Nashville. It‚Äôs been so much better. I have less financial stress, which leaves me able to give more emotional energy to my patients. Plus, the brick and mortar insurance-based PT practices around me charge around $500/session.

Rather than packages, I offer a small ‚Äúconsistency discount.‚Äù If someone commits to seeing me 1x/week for 6 weeks minimum, I give them a 5% discount. It incentivizes people by having a small discount and it fills my schedule with more reliability than selling packages. 5% isn‚Äôt much of a discount but it always makes people happy üòÉ and it‚Äôs not a burden to me financially.

post_text:
Anyone offer a stretch lab kind of a service. We are planning to introduce something similar in our clinic. I would like to learn more. Do we need any special certifications? Our clientele is patients with neurologic deficits.
Thank you.

comments.text:
Shouldn‚Äôt be any other certs needed‚Ä¶ I mean, you are a PT. 

We‚Äôve not pulled the trigger yet on doing this, but I do recommend going to a few Stretch Lab, Stretch Zone, Stretch MD sessions first.  See what they really do. 

I did. Booked the free one. Bought a package. Went and enjoyed. Pay close attention to how they do it. Figure out how you could do it better.  Figure out how you can spend 25min hands on, without stopping and giving the client an exercise to do on their own. I actually gave the stretch practitioner feedback for hand placement‚Ä¶ they were doing good but needed some refinement. 

Actually liked it enough that I looked into buying a franchise, but had my reasons and ended up not doing it. It truly wasn‚Äôt that expensive. 

BUT one of the things‚Ä¶.

Each visit is going to cost you b/w $30-$50 (package vs pay per visit). Great. That isn‚Äôt bad. 

But on the other end, that person is going to come to you and pay you $30 to $50. Which is a copay. Which kind of sucks. 

Now‚Ä¶I know this is an uncaged thing‚Ä¶ if you bill their insurance because they‚Äôre coming to you for a back or neck issue‚Ä¶ we‚Äôre talking much different money. A 23-25 minute stretch session billed as Neuro ReEd AND get the copay. 

So you market it this way‚Ä¶.‚Äùwhy go to a stretchy place and get stretched by a guy who spent a weekend in Lauderdale learning how to do this, when you can come to me ‚Äîwho did 8 years of school learning it‚Äî AND I can give you a couple of exercises to do at home as well. And if the stretching isn‚Äôt just exactly what you need‚Ä¶I can get more in depth. Maybe some dry needles. Maybe a quick crack. maybe a couple of strengthening things as well.‚Äù

Somebody has to say it, so I'll be that guy. I would hope we would use our education as PTs to rid the world of this nonsense. Neat for a feel-good treatment, but not for people seeking an evidence-based answer to their pain. I get that there's a market for it and money to be made, but it feels cheap to me and is harmful to the identity of our profession. If anyone is out there providing stand alone stretching as a service, they better not be asking why people don't understand what PTs do and what our education level is.

post_text: Hi all!  I‚Äôm currently running a cash based practice and considering credentialling with Medicare.   For those of you that have done so (preferably in the Virginia area) can you give me some insight into your reimbursement rates?  I can look up the fee schedule online but I realize this just gives me base numbers for each CPT code and that there are a lot of variables to this.  Trying to decide if it‚Äôs worth the hassle or not!

comments.text: AOTA has a calculator in their site that will take the deduction into account. I would use that if you are an OT. https://www.aota.org/practice/practice-essentials/coding/medicare-fee-schedule-calculator I suspect that APTA has the same for PT.

I just took the leap and did it this spring. I‚Äôm in MD, but I believe VA uses the same MAC (don‚Äôt quote me on that.) I was pleasantly surprised that it wasn‚Äôt as much of a hassle as I expected. I was credentialed very quickly, and the people at Novitas were very pleasant and helpful. My EMR takes care of all the submissions of claims and accounting without increasing my rate because I‚Äôm a solo practice and they are a small company. My business has doubled in revenue because I‚Äôm getting double what I was taking for ‚Äúnon-skilled wellness‚Äù visits. I don‚Äôt get what I get for cash clients, but it‚Äôs a reliable stream of income at about 80% of what my cash rate is, which is still great.

post_text:
Need some advice:
I have a mobile PT business where I see patients for self pay or through Med Part B.
Had a Chiropractor, who is an aquatence of my husband, ask to set up a deal with me to come into his office to see, primarily, Medicare patients bc he isn't a Medicare provider (he says he has tons of patients to give me...). He was talking about partnering together or me paying him part of the profit or rent. I really dont know what to say. I dont want to blow off a potential business deal/connection but not sure the legal aspect or how we'd bill (through my mobile company or his brick and mortar) This is all new to me as I have only been doing this a little over 1 year (but have been a PT for 14 and a manager of clinic for 12 of those years). Anyone who made similar partnerships or business deals can lead me in the right direction or give advice? I am in FL if that helps.

comments.text: I would question ‚Äúpartnering‚Äù in every sense of the word. I would treat it like you are renting a room or a space and keep your own business private. Paying rent is legal, giving him part of that is not. Ôøº
Paying him a piece of the profit is a kick back and is illegal!  He wants to pump up his Medicare revenue using you.

post_text:
What is your favorite tactic for increasing prices? some are on a package and others are pay per visit and others are continued per visit at the package price discounted rate for a coke more follow ups - what do you tell them? My brains too tired to find the right words. 

Aug 1 is my goal and I‚Äôm trying to figure out what‚Äôs ‚Äúfair‚Äù time wise to get info out.

comments.text:
I recommend personally telling your current clients face to face. Offer them the opportunity to purchase more sessions at their current rate, or give them a heads up on when you‚Äôll be raising the price. Treat them like VIP. Then send an email to your list - give them a chance to buy at ur old rate (if ur looking for a cash injection) and then start charging to new patients (who will be the first to pay the new price).

You don‚Äôt have to tell them why. In fact don‚Äôt justify. Just say you have a price increase. They don‚Äôt need to know the details.

Raise prices on new clients only..

Start AUG 1....     

And tell current clients prices are going up, yet you value them so much and as a thank you you will keep them on the original price 

WIN - WIN

Good luck

Offer them the opportunity to purchase more sessions at their current rate, or give them a heads up on when you‚Äôll be raising the price. Treat them like VIP. Then send an email to your list - give them a chance to buy at ur old rate (if ur looking for a cash injection) and then start charging to new patients (who will be the first to pay the new price).

You don‚Äôt have to tell them why. In fact don‚Äôt justify. Just say you have a price increase. They don‚Äôt need to know the details.

COMMENT 2: Raise prices on new clients only..

Start AUG 1....     

And tell current clients prices are going up, yet you value them so much and as a thank you you will keep them on the original price 

WIN - WIN

Good luck

post_text:
Anonymous because others in this group know me and I haven‚Äôt given my notice yet
Trying to decide about renting space in another town.
I currently rent space for $400. There is one other in my smallish town who do what I do. I take Medicare only and others are 100% cash.
I still work hh at 50% capacity. I am 90% booked.
I am ready to quit hh. my concern is consistently booking.
There comes question:
1/3 of my caseload comes from a town 40 min away. They don‚Äôt have anyone like me there, and even PT, they only have 2. 2 referral sources there consistently refer me people and always talk about how I need an office there because a lot of people they refer are not able to come to my town during day time. But would see me if I was in town. Cheapest office I can find there is $500/m
I am wondering if I should open an office there 2 days a week. I know I could fill 2 days a week and would provide consistency but that would be only 10 sessions max since my work is such I can‚Äôt see more than 5 a day and there is no one else trained (yet) to do what I do.
so not sure it is worth it? Thoughts?

comments.text: I think it should be based on what you want personally. I have made some decisions because I felt like I should and it‚Äôs hard to not be resentful over time. If you want to provide that service to that community and add the commute and cost of rental, then I think you should.

Just depends on your ROI.  I have 2 offices about 75 min apart.  One is way busier than the other.  I pay bills off the slow one and live off the busier.  The most frustrating thing you can do (I've been there) is just work to pay bills you wouldn't have if you didn't have an office.  If there's a good profit do it if not don't.

post_text:
Question for the group...
Background: I am a cashed-based PT. I have a gym that I work out of but also offer home visits. 
Situation: An acquaintance of mine would like me to come see his mother in her home for PT. She just had a knee replacement. She is doing PT at a physical therapy clinic. The plan is for her to continue therapy there but supplement with me. The primary purpose is she has pretty advanced dementia and can't remember her home exercises and can't remember to do them. Her children are all very busy during the week running their own companies. She does have aides. However, the aides do not feel comfortable helping her complete her home exercises. Her children are willing to sign an ABN.
Thoughts? Thank you in advance.

comments.text: You can‚Äôt use an ABN if you are not contracted with Medicare, but it can totally be a service you offer for a self pay rate.

My thoughts are first, medicate will not cover the extra visits per week and you could argue non skilled as you are taking the place of a family member. Either one of those reasonings alone would make this non covered service. I would feel comfortable offering this but you can decide how you feel about it. No ABN needed but I would be clear about there being no attempt to recover costs and all self pay.
