post_text:
I‚Äôm in the very very early stages of starting my own practice. A friend (think a little more than acquaintance) asked me to see her kiddo. We‚Äôve had a couple of phone calls with mom debating if the kiddo needed to be seen. A few weeks later and I‚Äôm scheduled to see them Thursday. Mom mentioned that she wants to pay me to do this informal assessment. 

So here is the question: do I charge full price or provide a friend discount, especially considering I am JUST leaving my current job and going out on my own. No standardized tests etc. 

Thank you for any insight!

comments.text: I‚Äôd provide discount and ask if she‚Äôs pleased, if she would do a Google review, refer friends, etc.

You value yourself by the price you charge. Also, when people PAY, they PAY ATTENTION. During the height of C-vd I was giving away advice to friends who were pregnant and realized I resented them bc they weren't following through on my advice... but they had no investment so where was the incentive? Value yourself, and that yes you can help them. We teach people how to treat us and this is no different.

post_text: I‚Äôm an OT and have a sole proprietorship. I have a contract for BCBS but the bulk of my patients are cash paying (more for personal training services.) I‚Äôm toying with hiring a contract PT to work VERY casually (2-8 patients/week.) If I get her a BCBS shield contract, how do I manage billing and paying her? She will get 70% of my cash rate charge. Do you also think it should be 70% or whatever she‚Äôs billing (will be substantially more.)

comments.text: I have done this in the past and I was paid a flat rate per patient. I was happy and so was the employer! Can you talk with the person to see what they think is fair?! Your cash rates might be higher than what BCBS reimburses, but I never like being incentivized for what I bill out. I like to bill what the patient needs. Just a thought!
I'd do a percentage of your average reimbursement/cash pay per visit looking at the past 6-12 months.

post_text:
Hi all! SLP here. I put in my notice to be done in June. I plan on working on the logistics for the summer and hitting the ground running with my own practice in the fall. 

One of the things I‚Äôm struggling with is the private pay structure - 100%, I‚Äôm not dealing with insurance but I also want to find a way to service the people who are not able to private pay. Isn‚Äôt private pay only sustainable to the few (client, wise?). TIA!

comments.text:
Private pay is sustainable but, as with most things in the therapy world, it depends. It depends on your clientele, skill set, niche, etc. 

Not all insurances are hard to deal with and not all insurances are bad. You can pick and choose how you work with what insurances and when. 

There are plenty of options to fit you, your practice and your patients. 

Good luck! And congrats!

Private pay is possible for those who value your service. I've had patients tell me that they rather use their insurance and could not afford to pay OOP and then contact me a few weeks later asking to schedule. If the service you provide is of value, then people will pay for the care they need and deserve.

post_text:
Advice! I‚Äôm ready to start seeing patients on a cash basis for a side hustle - ultimate goal will be to be solely on my own and out of corporate world. 

BUT I‚Äôm struggling to see how to get it to leap from side hustle to full time without that big income lag. We literally cannot afford for me to not have my income during any period of time (husband a teacher, two small kids, building a house‚Ä¶) How do you do this!?!

comments.text: I started mine on the side as well after I switched to PRN from full time OP. Due to the natural fluctuation of business, I still do PRN but the roles have reversed. PRN is now the side gig and my business is about 70% full. I have kept prn for security when I have slow months‚Ä¶this is my situation at 1.5 years in. Organic growth takes time, so if you can manage building it on the side for a while, that may be best until you have consistent and more predictable business income

COMMENT 1: I started mine on the side as well after I switched to PRN from full time OP. Due to the natural fluctuation of business, I still do PRN but the roles have reversed. PRN is now the side gig and my business is about 70% full. I have kept prn for security when I have slow months‚Ä¶this is my situation at 1.5 years in. Organic growth takes time, so if you can manage building it on the side for a while, that may be best until you have consistent and more predictable business income

post_text: For those in gym spaces, any advice for setting up a lease agreement with a gym? Such as, what are some things to be mindful of when drawing up the lease agreement, rent prices, etc. Insight or any clinical pearls would be appreciated. Thank you!

comments.text: generally speaking, keep the gym out of your books...... meaning, flat rate price is fine, price per patient is fine, % of profits, not fine.
I do a flat 20% for 19 months now. Has worked out well. Months vary but it all evens out.

COMMENT 1: generally speaking, keep the gym out of your books...... meaning, flat rate price is fine, price per patient is fine, % of profits, not fine.

COMMENT 2: I do a flat 20% for 19 months now. Has worked out well. Months vary but it all evens out.

post_text: When y‚Äôall are figuring out package pricing is there a rule of thumb you use or how do you determine how much to take off when someone does a 4 session, 6 session, 8, etc?

comments.text: I decided what I wanted my ‚Äúminimum‚Äù rate to be, and calculated the math up from there. For my six visit package, I offer 5% off if they commit to 6 but choose to pay as they go, or 10% if they pay for all in advance. If they choose a 10 visit package, they get a 10% discount to pay as they go, or 15% to pay up front. I have a policy for how long they have to redeem those visits, and what happens if they don‚Äôt use all the visits in the allotted time.

Lots of ways to go about this. Just make sure that your "best price" is not lower than the session rate you need to stay viable. (I.e., if everyone bought sessions at your best rate, you would still be able to pay your business bills and pay yourself a living wage.)

I don't do packages, per se. If they buy the full POC that I propose at eval, they get my POC discount. Anything other than that is a percentage upcharge, based on my personal "minimum" rate.

full_thread_text:
POST: When y‚Äôall are figuring out package pricing is there a rule of thumb you use or how do you determine how much to take off when someone does a 4 session, 6 session, 8, etc?

COMMENT 1: I decided what I wanted my ‚Äúminimum‚Äù rate to be, and calculated the math up from there. For my six visit package, I offer 5% off if they commit to 6 but choose to pay as they go, or 10% if they pay for all in advance. If they choose a 10 visit package, they get a 10% discount to pay as they go, or 15% to pay up front. I have a policy for how long they have to redeem those visits, and what happens if they don‚Äôt use all the visits in the allotted time.

COMMENT 2: Lots of ways to go about this. Just make sure that your "best price" is not lower than the session rate you need to stay viable. (I.e., if everyone bought sessions at your best rate, you would still be able to pay your business bills and pay yourself a living wage.)

I don't do packages, per se. If they buy the full POC that I propose at eval, they get my POC discount. Anything other than that is a percentage upcharge, based on my personal "minimum" rate.

post_text: For the mobile therapists, do you collect payment before or after sessions?  Has anyone had a problem with patient trying to not pay after a session?

comments.text: Nope, they always pay. I have them sign all financial agreements beforehand. Explain the cost up front, so no chance for misinterpretation
If I know there is a copayment collect at time of service. I use IvyPay for that. Also accept check or cash. Not had a problem yet.

full_thread_text:
POST: For the mobile therapists, do you collect payment before or after sessions?  Has anyone had a problem with patient trying to not pay after a session?

COMMENT 1: Nope, they always pay. I have them sign all financial agreements beforehand. Explain the cost up front, so no chance for misinterpretation

COMMENT 2: If I know there is a copayment collect at time of service. I use IvyPay for that. Also accept check or cash. Not had a problem yet.

Hi y'all. Wanted to get a sense of what I should be asking for a workshop I may potentially do. 
It's not meant to make bank or promote an offer. just trying to help people out with some information.
If I would do it on my own, it would be really informal and I would have done it at a low cost for the participants and hope to get at least 30 people attending for 10 dollars each.
I am in talks with an organization (in Montreal, Canada) that is interested to join me for it. If I contract it to the non profit, I can choose my rate and hope they have the budget for it. They will not be charging the participants. So i don't want to highball it but don't want to lowball it.
It will take some prep on my part and be about 90 minutes. 
Do I charge my hourly rate (That people pay to see me)? because that may be too high for them to afford. but I also don't know how much they can afford. I don't want to name them but for context, this non profit provides medical, legal and social services to Montreal youth. they have a number of medical, social, and legal services including: Information and referrals,, Medical clinics, Legal assistance and consultations, counseling, and Workshops on legal rights, safer drug use, babysitting and other social topics such as self-esteem, body-image, and boundaries. (showing that they are a more liberal organization and likely use their money to help people ++ if that means anything).
TL:DR: how do I come up with a rate? If I DO highball it, and they say no, you think they'll be ok to negotiate for something they can work with?
Thanks a lot
Feel free to message me if you are more comfortable with that

comments.text: Don‚Äôt speculate what they can afford. Just use your normal rate for the time for the workshop and any prep time. You can always lower it if they come back and say that it‚Äôs too much for them. If they are offering to cover it all in the first place they will be willing to negotiate.

post_text:
I‚Äôve been a cash based therapist and personal trainer for a year now working out of my home studio. 

I‚Äôm still really struggling with my fees. My therapy clients are my easiest. I see them, they leave, and I‚Äôm done. My personal training clients require significant more work. I see them, they leave, then I‚Äôm busy making exercise programs for them, finding an inspiring podcast or article for them to read, analyzing their nutrition logs for them, etc. 

It seems as if I should be charging more for using the skills of my therapy/masters degree, however so much more work is involved with my personal training clients. 

1/2 my clients get a combo of both services. So how would you break down fees for services? Just have a flat fee for all my services regardless of what they are receiving?

My other problem is 50-75% of people that email me inquiring my service rates don‚Äôt respond after I tell them. In comparison to all the other local gyms (I did my research) I‚Äôm on the lower side. 

Thoughts? 
(Latest social media post photo for the hell of it.)

comments.text: Same rate you offer your rehab patients. You are practicing at your highest degree and your admin time should be considered.

Personally I‚Äôd charge a higher price point because although I may wear  many hats, what‚Äôs underneath the hat is always the same.  You‚Äôre always going to be thinking at your highest skill level and you‚Äôre a good PT who cares about motivating your clients, know your value. The clients who pay for having a good PT who also trains (because it‚Äôs not as common as you may think) are the ones you want to keep anyway. 

Charge more so you can provide a better product and ultimately work less

post_text:
Food for thought. 

You get home from work and realize you are locked out of your house. You call a locksmith. They come out and within three minutes. You are inside. They charge you $100. 

Ôøº same scenario ..it takes them 30 minutes to get you inside your house. They charge you $100. Which scenario do you like better? 

The average person will pay 50% more to wait 50% less   ü´†üíØ‚úÖÔøº

comments.text:
The problem with these comparisons is that forever, we as therapists are in a health care system that has paid for services with insurance. 
Trainers and acupuncturists and massage therapists have never been part of the insurance system. It will take a long time and much persistence and change for us to be seen differently‚Ä¶.people pay a lot for their insurance every month and want to use it when they can. It‚Äôs a tough position to be in but it‚Äôs where we are as therapists.
Also, an average locksmith should get you in the house in 1 visit. Even great PT will/should often take multiple visits for the problem to truly be solved.

post_text: For anyone who is self-employed, who do you use for health insurance? I gave up full-time benefits at my previous job to pursue my own business, but I need health insurance for myself and my three kids. Not sure where to start or what insurance carrier doesn‚Äôt cost an arm and a leg. Thank you!

comments.text: I use Christian Healthcare Ministries. It‚Äôs a cost sharing plan, but has been phenomenal. Case I‚Äôm point‚Ä¶my labrum repair with BCBS cost me nearly $8000 in ADDITION to premiums that were close to $1000/mo for the 3 of us. Clavicle repair in 2019 with CHM cost me $0 with premiums of about $400-450/month for us 3. Wife got tossed from her horse and literally landed on her head resulting in just a concussion thank goodness, but also a $35K ER bill. Again we paid $0. You pay OOP for routine stuff, but well worth it imo.

We use Medi share! We pay 400 a month for a family plan with 8k family ‚Äúdeductible‚Äù. A local direct primary care doctor told me about Zion as well, which is a sharing program but is not faith based in nature.

post_text:
I feel bad even asking this but I cannot find any posts that simply just came out and asked‚Ä¶

How much do you earn doing this: 

1. As a side hustle

2. Full time 

Feel free to message me privately if you don‚Äôt want to post that on here but I would truly appreciate actually seeing some numbers. It‚Äôs just tough bc I make 120k a year as a director for several out patient/ personal injury clinics (a very easy/stress free job) and have had colleagues tell me I‚Äôd be insane to leave and open my own cash based mobile clinic. 

I feel like I‚Äôd be successful but I don‚Äôt have an idea of what ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù even looks like in terms of money.

comments.text:
2020 was my first year full time in business.  I‚Äôve brought in $100-120k revenue each year.  

I could have brought in more than 120k in 2022 if I wanted to prioritize it, but I did a lot of non-work things instead‚Ä¶..

What being self-employed allowed me to do in 2022:  
I decided to stop focusing on the business and rather focus on my mental and physical health.
I paid myself as an employee 65k.  

I camped and hiked 1-2 times a month April-Oct.
I improved my hiking ability from 5 miles to 22 miles ‚Äî hiked Mt Whitney last September! I also hiked the tallest mountains in NC & VA.

Spent 2 weeks in Mexico.  1 week in California.  A week in the mountains with my sister and nephews.

I took up Olympic Weightlifting 8 hours/week.  Learned some Spanish.  Took a mentorship course and several other PT courses.  

I did a landscaping project and other home projects ‚Äî paid for by the business (I work out of my home).

I did a lot of bodywork and psychotherapy.  

I did almost no marketing and stayed busy with word of mouth.  I saw 16-20 clients a week @ $149.

This year, 2023, raised my rates to $170 so I can max out my week at 18 clients.
My goal is to be an intermediate Spanish speaker by the end of the year.  Continue with Olympic weightlifting, get back into Pole dancing, and learn about rappelling/Canyoneering to prepare for 3 weeks in the Azores this fall.

Success to me is owning my own time. Ôøº Do I make a little bit more than working for an employer? Yes. But that‚Äôs just the tip of the iceberg. Ôøº I don‚Äôt have to ask anyone permission for Ôøº anything

post_text:
Posted this in another group and got no traction so hoping you guys might have some insight. Sorry to those where it‚Äôs crossposted‚Ä¶..

Had a random thought about overall payment structure. I know many offer discounts for bulk purchase of sessions, and some offer monthly subscription services. However, has anyone ever successfully implemented extended payment plans to overcome the upfront cost in low-income areas? 

I know there are a handful of quite successful cash-based practitioners in my area that are crushing it (Love seeing your success Russ, Sean, Mike, Derek), but they are all based in more affluent neighborhoods of the region. While I ended up taking an insurance based position when I moved for stability while I focused my energies on growing my online services, current familial and clinical ownership changes might be re-invigorating the drive to get out of the mill and I‚Äôm thinking through potential hurdles as I rebuild the business plan.

comments.text: Another option is to bill out of network instead of being strictly cash based. It‚Äôs a little bit tricky at first because you have to find out which plans are worth submitting vs just collecting your cash rate up front and having the patient submit a superbill on their own, but if you can figure out which ones are worth it, you will likely get paid more than your discounted package rate.

I‚Äôve done a payment plans for splitting the package into a maximum of 3 payments spread out throughout the plan of care with the last payment having to be paid before the last session. I have never done extended payment plans beyond the plan of care.

post_text:
I see there is a lot of information available on this, but reading up on it shows there are a number of important variables to consider. 

I just got off the phone with someone who would like me to work with her and her son, both of whom are covered by their auto insurance (Farmer's) for an MVA in November that was not their fault.  Her understanding is that Farmers will then sue Geico (the at-fault driver's insurance). 

I am a mobile, out-of-network provider in Washington State.  I do provide Superbills, but collect payment from the client.  What are the steps I or this prospective client should take to ensure they are reimbursed for my services?

What other tips do you have for me?

comments.text: initially their PIP would cover not just your fee, but any medical fees incurred from the accident.  since mva in Nov, that mo e may be gone thru ambulance, MD's etc.  PIP is usually 2500-10K.  after PIP exhausted, payment would then come from ins carrier or patient.  atsettlement, everyone gets reimbursed. including ins carriers and any attorney fees.  I would provided your normal fee for service with super bill or hcfa form provided for pt. for reimbursement.  you could also file these with auto company and their private carrier.  in my state, it must be hcfa, no superbills.,
Start with reaching out to the adjuster. They will tell you what they reimburse per visit. Then the client will have an idea what they can expect to be reimbursed.  That‚Äôs where I would start.

post_text:
I am contemplating adding a subscription type service for PT.  A monthly fee.  I am wondering if anyone here had successfully done something like this?  

I starting completely mobile, but am now hybrid.  I want to grow my in person/clinic visits and hoping to add some value by doing this.  

Any insight from someone who has done thus would be appreciated.

comments.text:
The concept works. It makes it easier from a billing standpoint. Allows for less administrative work. 

Your best bet is to limit how many visits per month. Plus you need a certain number of people ready to sign up. 

Say you only have 15 people the first 6 months that have subscriptions. If you're charging $200 to $250 per month, you're only bringing in $3000 to $3750. It would seem like charging more would be the thing, but people are already paying monthly for health insurance. If you're in a more affluent location, this may be fine. So location/population are key factors. Also having enough people that want to sign up for it. 

Subscription models for PT aren't common and it may take more convincing for others to join.

Pairing up with organizations/clinics that do concierge model of Healthcare is important.

I don't have all the answers to this model. I've been trying it out for a while. It has its plus and minuses.
I'd be interested if anybody does this monthly subscription model for PT in states like California where you'd have to get the POC signed within 30 days or X # visits.

comments.text: by law, the insured is obligated to pay the contractual rate on their their ins. contract to the provider.  it sounds as if the MD office is the provider and they are paying you a cleverly described salary and bonus.  does not sound uncaged to me but I think further info/attorney consult are needed.
Just be cautious of anything that may be perceived as fee splitting   I'd have a lawyer check anything

post_text: Has anyone here worked in home health before? What did you like or not like about it? Any tips or suggestions for success when working on your own?

comments.text: It‚Äôs been great for me as I build my cash business. Flexibility, night before scheduling, choose how many people is see, get to volunteer in my kids schools. You go from mansions to hoarder homes, it‚Äôs eclectic but overall I‚Äôm happy I did it. I started 6 months ago after 12+ years in outpatient setting so was transition for me! Documentation is kind of brutual but once you get used to it and we use scribe service it‚Äôs more doable.

Oof where to start haha. 

I have worked home health for 6 years. I work PRN for 3 companies now. At first it was great; higher pay than the hospital at pay per visit. I lived in a city where patients were close together so drive time wasn‚Äôt bad, could see 8 patients a day easily. Documentation wasn‚Äôt terrible but longer than most settings. 

NOW 6 years in‚Ä¶I have never received a pay raise. I ask often and try to demonstrate my value. But PRN is a hard rate to increase. I work more rural now since moving to my current city. More drive time, less patients, lots of time where I‚Äôm not being paid. The documentation has drastically increased in the past years. 20-30 minutes per patient now. Insurances delegating how many visits we can have. Lowly motivated patients. Poor home environments. All parts of home health. As a supplement to income PRN can be fantastic. But even I‚Äôm burning out on it. Large companies seem to care very little about the actual clinician. I‚Äôve had 6 nurses quit in 2 months with 2 of my companies. Burnout is high. 

I will be staying PRN while starting my mobile outpatient and it will be fantastic to have more steady income. But it has been pushing me out of its own system the past 6 months and I‚Äôll be happy to leave.

post_text: Curious if anyone is raising their rates in 2023 and if so, how much?

comments.text: If your supplies, rest, or any costs of doing business is going up, then yes, you probably should consider it.  If your turning a good profit and that margin isn‚Äôt changing much then no you shouldn‚Äôt.

I am increasing $10 a visit in the new year. This works out to be about 6% increase. I have had zero pushback from patients that I have notified so far. If anything I have had several patients tell me they are happy for me that I am charging more because they know how expensive everything is anymore. Everyone's situation is different and you have to do what works for you.

full_thread_text:
POST: Curious if anyone is raising their rates in 2023 and if so, how much?

COMMENT 1: If your supplies, rest, or any costs of doing business is going up, then yes, you probably should consider it.  If your turning a good profit and that margin isn‚Äôt changing much then no you shouldn‚Äôt.

COMMENT 2: I am increasing $10 a visit in the new year. This works out to be about 6% increase. I have had zero pushback from patients that I have notified so far. If anything I have had several patients tell me they are happy for me that I am charging more because they know how expensive everything is anymore. Everyone's situation is different and you have to do what works for you.

post_text:
Hi all! Do superbills need to be broken down by cost per CPT code or is the total charge of all CPT codes sufficient? Example (for simple math) 
Option 1:
2 units 97110 = $50
2 units 97112 = $50 
total = $100

Option 2 (can it just be listed?) 
2 units 97110
2 units 97112
total = $100

comments.text: Your CPT codes do not need to equal the cost off the visit. You can charge $70 per CPT code and cahrge a flat fee of $150. Insurance will reimbure the patient based on $150 but the data will be input for CPT codes in your area at $70 per unit

I've heard of people charging a certain rate per unit that will equal higher than the cash pay rate, then adding another line item to bring the rate down to the cash pay rate. IE if your cash pay rate was $250...
 1 unit Therex $100
1 unit manual $100
1 unit therapy $100
Provider Discount -$50.

post_text:
As an idependent contractor for a rural outpatient clinic, I‚Äôm thinking I can inform the clinic of an increase in my IC rate change and allow them two weeks notice. I‚Äôd like to add a 7-10% increase in my rate. It hasn‚Äôt changed since 2020. 

I did request a raise several months ago, but was told it‚Äôs not possible due to one of the clinics that are overall not bringing in a profit. I drive to all of their clinics, though mainly needed at that one.

They gave me a single/temporary bonus at the time.

The business owns multiple clinics for 2+ years. They also have school contracts and hospital contracts. I know they need to maintain my employment at this time. I know my productivity is profitable. 

Instead of asking for a raise (like a W2 employee would), as an IC, I‚Äôd like to stand my ground and set my own rate.

This is a reasonable increase in rate. 

I am working my own business, but not more than 4-8 hours a week. Thankfully, I created for myself a boost to my income this way. 

Has anyone set there rate increase as IC, with a notice, and how did it go?

Are they taking advantage of my willingness to accept their rate?

comments.text: u r correct.  as an IC, you set your rate, they decide if they want to hire you for that rate.  u do  not have to ask for the raise.  there is a chance they look elsewhere for IC help but I with the labor shortage and your familiarity with how they run their offices that option is not likely.  Their issue of the 1 clinic that is not too profitable is their problem, not yours.  I would give more like 30 days.  say 1/1/2023.  your request is reasonable.
I gave one of mine 10% increase 4 months ago when she asked

post_text: is anyone in network with Aetna?  How is their fee schedule?

comments.text: We dropped Aetna. Their intermediary is Holista. They pay us $35 a visit if you see patient for 10 visits. If you see them for 20 visits, then it will be $17.5 including patient's copay. They pay like DRG. For RC tendonitis, this is how you will be paid. Aetna does not manage new providers. Those that were providers 2 years prior have better rates. Do not accept without asking how you will be paid. If you see patient beyond 3 visits, you may not sign up with them. You can not bill patient for extra since you have contract with them.
They aren‚Äôt not a good payer in Texas‚Ä¶ at my current employer they pay about $60-70 a visit.

post_text:
Hi everyone! What are your thoughts on this?

I literally just started my "side hustle" cash-based business (I have two clients right now) as I'm still employed with my F/T job. I don't want to leave my F/T job for personal reasons. My only available hours to see potential patients would be from 5:30-8PM. I offer PT, personal training and recovery services.

A nearby gym has offered me to use their space and market my business to their members. They are allowing me to have full access to their 1000 sq ft gym with office/private room/equipment availability. The rent would depend on how many people I attract but the low end would be $1000/month (not sure what that means -- why can't it be a fixed amount?). If I only saw 2-3 patients/week, they said it wouldn't be worth it. I think I can cover the lower end of the monthly rent with one person's 10-session package BUT I'm worried about "will I have time for myself?", "will seeing 10 patients/week be too overwhelming?", "what if I can't even get people to buy in my services and now I have to cough up my own money to pay the rent" if I end up going this route. I eventually declined the offer for the moment but felt this might be a great opportunity.

comments.text:
$1000/month for a 1000 Sq ft gym seems excessive. See if they are willing to give you a per hour rate. I pay $25/hour where I do side stuff. Normally only a few patients per week.
A per month rate that high would only make sense if you are there full time.
At first glance that sounds too high of rent for so a side hustle. If they really wanted you, I would try to negotiate a percentage of your billed amount.

post_text:
I‚Äôm trying to get an idea of pricing structures for my cash-based mobile business. Mostly I will be offering services out of my jiu jitsu gym for our athletes. The gym owner is requiring a 30% cut which is not ideal but it‚Äôs what he is already charging other professionals to use the facilities so I can‚Äôt negotiate it. I train at a ‚Äúbougie gym‚Äù in a relatively affluent area (Cary, NC). I am dry needling certified and considering offering DN only packages in addition to traditional PT POC. 

In looking at other cash-based practices in our region I could charge anywhere from $75-225 for an eval and given that 60% of that will go to the gym owner and taxes, I‚Äôm probably going to have to go toward the higher end of that to make it worth my while. But I am unsure how to price follow ups and DN/manual therapy only packages. Someone has mentioned to me charging by the minute or by CPT code but again, not sure how to price that and make it viable for me. This is a side gig for now but I‚Äôm hoping to grow it. 

Any suggestions? What has worked for you all?

comments.text: I believe, depending on various state practice acts, you are protected against giving away a percentage of your income. For instance, when creating a rental agreement, you may be able to negotiate a fixed price (per hour, treatment session, whatever) rather than a percentage so if you change your rates based on demand, experience, etc the person renting to you is not further ‚Äúprofiting‚Äù off your degree & license. I would highly reconsider‚Ä¶ I was in a similar situation with someone renting to me for a percentage but have switched locations where I now pay an hourly rent for the space and it‚Äôs a much smoother deal.
I would find a different place. If you are training at the gym and you already have rapport with people they will definitely come see you whether you are in the gym or not. 30-40% is not sustainable.

post_text:
If you went from insurance to cash, how did you notify your clients of the change? Did you send an email? Give them a letter during visit? If you sent an email or sent a letter would you mind sharing it with me? 
I don‚Äôt have email of all my clients‚Ä¶ change is happening January 1st. Felt it would give enough time to close POCs, make plans, etc. plus most people are stuck with deductibles and what not in January any way‚Ä¶ 

Steps I thought of: 
1. Write a letter an email explaining change, what out of network means‚Ä¶ In the letter I‚Äôd let them know of single visit price, a package that may work for them, and a special promotion‚Ä¶ like my cash rate is $150, but current insurance patients will get a chance to pre-purchase up to 10 sessions at a much lower rate $120-130‚Ä¶ not sure‚Ä¶ 
2. Starting after thanksgiving I‚Äôd give the letter to everyone by the end of session (ideally I‚Äôd have time to explain, but not sure I do with every session).

Thoughts?

Ps: I will also start my cancelation policy and require a card on file to all patients as of Jan 1st (will have patient sign paperwork etc). Would love some tips on how to disclose that in the nicest way‚Ä¶

comments.text:
Your clients are going to want to know why they should pay cash vs going somewhere that takes their insurance.
You might want to come up with a list of positives for them as to why cash is to their benefit

post_text:
For those who use PTEverywhere, and bill Medicare. I already have the clearing house set up, but when trying to create my CMS1500, when scrubbing it, it says I need to create an invoice first. 

Any input on what I do from here? I think I know how to create the invoice after playing around, but what do you put for the $$ for the CPT codes? Do you put what you know Medicare pays, or just an average payment, like $75 per unit or $125 or $150 for eval?

comments.text: Put whatever you want to charge, more than Medicare rates, and Medicare is going to adjust it to their rates anyway. After you create the invoice for that DOS, then you can go back to the claim and scrub it

I don't use PT everywhere but you can put whatever you charge per unit. For example I charge $50 a unit and $150 for an eval. So a lot of my visits I would be charging $200 but Medicare will only pay the allowable. They automatically adjust that on the claim.

That is my set fee schedule that I use for everything so I don't have to change it around and technically I think your fee schedule is supposed to be the same for everyone.

The exception is you can offer prompt pay discounts for people who pay cash and things like that.

But hopefully someone who uses PT everywhere will chime in

comments.text:
I am mobile I charge 150 for an eval 125 a visit. I typically stay in a small area.  I know two other therapists in my area who do clinic based cash PT, one charges 160 an  hour, with an intro price on the eval of 87 to get people in the door,  the other one 225   for an eval or visit. She has a very specific niche‚Ä¶ runners.  Both own their own clinic with a second or third PT working with them.  

  I realize my prices are lower and I am mobile,  but some of my patients actually see me more than 1 times a week whereas with their business model they often will see someone and then have them come back maybe once a week, every 10 days,  or every other week, etc.
Thank you all so much. I live in FL. I wanted to make sure I'm fair across the board but also making a realistic business decision.

  I realize my prices are lower and I am mobile,  but some of my patients actually see me more than 1 times a week whereas with their business model they often will see someone and then have them come back maybe once a week, every 10 days,  or every other week, etc.

post_text: I have started doing cash based PT at a local gym. I am paying the gym owner $20/visit, with max of $1200/month for therapy visits. Obviously I don't want to pay $20 of my $50 session. Any advice would be appreciated!

comments.text: Hey Logan I definitely wouldn‚Äôt do a percentage split because then they‚Äôll know how much you make and most likely will try to raise your rent. I like others ideas of charging by the hour as long as you can keep your cap and you can always raise your rates

I wouldn‚Äôt do per session but per hour. That way if you have a shorter session like 30 min needling session it would only be $10 vs $20. Also consider raising your rates. I pay $25 an hour for a similar situation.

post_text: Does anyone here do memberships? If so, how do you structure them? I‚Äôm thinking that my postpartum clients need at least a 3 month membership options to return to exercise.

comments.text: I do a monthly membership for maintenance or fitness programming. They either get one 30 minute check in monthly to update/progress plan or 2- 30 minute check ins if they need more coaching‚Ä¶. The rate differs for 1 vs 2 check-ins. The membership is billed every 4 weeks and continues until they cancel.

I do them and have a three month minimum upon signup. Members get one visit a month for 60 minutes or two 30 minute visits a month, along with percentage off any further visits within the month if they desire it.

full_thread_text:
POST: Does anyone here do memberships? If so, how do you structure them? I‚Äôm thinking that my postpartum clients need at least a 3 month membership options to return to exercise.

COMMENT 1: I do a monthly membership for maintenance or fitness programming. They either get one 30 minute check in monthly to update/progress plan or 2- 30 minute check ins if they need more coaching‚Ä¶. The rate differs for 1 vs 2 check-ins. The membership is billed every 4 weeks and continues until they cancel.

COMMENT 2: I do them and have a three month minimum upon signup. Members get one visit a month for 60 minutes or two 30 minute visits a month, along with percentage off any further visits within the month if they desire it.

post_text: What HEP apps is everyone using?  I want something that will do RTM.

comments.text: I use switchback health app. Been loving it so far and was built by a PT for PTs.

I think truecoach does this where you can have a dialogue with patients directly through the app. In theory this is great but it isn't cheap. Medbridge allows for patients to check in but not sure if it allows for dialogue. Also medbridge makes it really difficult and not pretty to make workout splits, ie different exercise on M/W/F while true coach allows that pretty easily. 

Because of this, I just use google sheets with commenting turned on. If i had more cash pay patients, I'd probably use true coach .

post_text:
Hey all! 
For those of you who are cash based providers and provide super-bills for out-of-network reimbursement... riddle me this situation described below. 

Let's say you charge $100 per visit for your cash based services over the course of a 60-min session (unrealistic i know... but simplistic math). If i have a CPT Code based fee schedule of $25/unit and I typically bill 4 units to reach my cash based per visit rate... but i only see that patient for 3 units worth of treatment, and the patient payed the full $100 going rate for my treatment at the point of service. What will reimbursement from their insurance look like when the patient submits a superbill where the services performed don't align with total amount paid by the patient? Total cost paid by patient would be $100... total units billed to insurance for reimbursement would be $75 because of 3 units charged. Would this be a problem?

Side note... do a lot of cash based PT's bill off of a CPT code based fee schedule? Also do you bill units from AMA or 8-min rule guidelines?

Any information and recommendations would be helpful for myself as a new owner! Thanks all! I look forward to some great discussion below in the comments!

comments.text: But how does it work for patient reimbursement if your PP rate us $100, your billable are $300, check goes to the patient. They might be getting $200 reimbursement
Also, if your PP rate is $100, you opt to have the check to you, $300 is applied to the deductible?

post_text: Has anyone employed someone at salary and then anything over the minimum pay them per patient ? do you see any drawbacks to this method?

comments.text: I have previously worked as an employee with this compensation structure in an OP Ortho cash-based setting. I liked it because I always had a guaranteed floor, and it made it was less stressful for me vs pure commission. Make the cap obtainable though so they are motivated to get to it, yet not discouraged that they won't be able to. If the cap where they make more is too high or too aggressive it may shoot you in the foot.
This is how most part A HH agencies do things, or they have no salary and everyone is pay per visit.

full_thread_text:
POST: Has anyone employed someone at salary and then anything over the minimum pay them per patient ? do you see any drawbacks to this method?

COMMENT 1: I have previously worked as an employee with this compensation structure in an OP Ortho cash-based setting. I liked it because I always had a guaranteed floor, and it made it was less stressful for me vs pure commission. Make the cap obtainable though so they are motivated to get to it, yet not discouraged that they won't be able to. If the cap where they make more is too high or too aggressive it may shoot you in the foot.

COMMENT 2: This is how most part A HH agencies do things, or they have no salary and everyone is pay per visit.

post_text:
Win and Lesson!

I started with the idea of having a mobile physical therapy practice, just me, resigned to the idea that I will likely have to rely on Medicare payment as my source of income, because people in my area won't want to pay cash for my services. This would limit my earning potential as I can only see so many people in a day and Medicare will only pay so much, but as long as I can replace my corporate job paycheck, it will be good enough.

I found out about the Uncaged Clinician coaching program and thought, "Well that sounds great, but there is no way I can afford to pay for that and recoup the cost considering the (perceived) ceiling of my income." And, I will admit, I'm on the cheap side when it comes to paying for things, so the program seemed very cost-prohibitive for me. Not.gonna.do.it.

I was willing to talk to [Keghan Crossland](https://www.facebook.com/groups/252761052764366/user/548311312/?__cft__[0]=AZU8HqJlgHPyNxm4L0VPPL86p49te_ONVgpLnPiR1ZngfgvYZ7p7A8aVIhDX_lW2cAfOPdZ2n3r1CiE4NOfORoZjRax5x8UdbU_pRJ94lVpKVlelx_Dd48IJbyyFYrBwjb1miO5IM9jGlUFwPNP4dkeE&__tn__=-]K-R), though, because you know, *free.* He then told me that I should at least do a growth strategy call with [David Bayliff](https://www.facebook.com/groups/252761052764366/user/1269938479/?__cft__[0]=AZU8HqJlgHPyNxm4L0VPPL86p49te_ONVgpLnPiR1ZngfgvYZ7p7A8aVIhDX_lW2cAfOPdZ2n3r1CiE4NOfORoZjRax5x8UdbU_pRJ94lVpKVlelx_Dd48IJbyyFYrBwjb1miO5IM9jGlUFwPNP4dkeE&__tn__=-]K-R). I mean, I'm still not going to pay for the program, but, what the heck, it's *free.*

So, I talked to David, and then...I started to really see the value of the program...that this *could* be an investment in myself to grow a business bigger than what I originally thought. "Am I just drinking the Kool-aid," I thought? It's still a lot of money. Money that I don't currently have. But I was seriously considering it.

Then I had the opportunity to reach out and speak to someone went through the program and started her own successful mobile PT practice.  She graciously and generously answered my business related questions and also shared her experience with the Uncaged Clinician coaching program...and that sealed the deal.  And so now, I am officially a member of the Uncaged Clinician Pathway program!

So the lesson here: I was not interested in paying for this program at all, BUT, after learning more about it, I was able to realize the value that it offers me. So now I am working on changing my mindset. There are people out there that will not be interested in paying cash for my services, BUT if I can show them the value it provides to them, I just might change their minds like I changed my mind.

And there is the power of word of mouth. I mean, while I was very interested in the program after talking to David, it still felt like a lot of money. But after talking to someone who experienced it and valued it (someone that I didn't even know), I felt good about committing myself to the program.

So here I am, so excited to be a part of the program and for the possibilities that await. Let's GOOOO!

comments.text:
SO. MUCH. VALUE. HERE. 
üôåüôåüôåüî•üî•üî•üî•

Thank you for sharing, Jill Raibley Howery!!!

I love how you‚Äôre already applying this to your future customers and gaining insight. 

Gaining trust and demonstrating value takes time and a few touch points ‚Äî and that‚Äôs ok. 

I have a hunch you‚Äôre going to blow your initial expectations for your business out of the water! üëèüèº

She graciously and generously answered my business related questions and also shared her experience with the Uncaged Clinician coaching program...and that sealed the deal.  And so now, I am officially a member of the Uncaged Clinician Pathway program!

So the lesson here: I was not interested in paying for this program at all, BUT, after learning more about it, I was able to realize the value that it offers me. So now I am working on changing my mindset. There are people out there that will not be interested in paying cash for my services, BUT if I can show them the value it provides to them, I just might change their minds like I changed my mind.

And there is the power of word of mouth. I mean, while I was very interested in the program after talking to David, it still felt like a lot of money. But after talking to someone who experienced it and valued it (someone that I didn't even know), I felt good about committing myself to the program.

So here I am, so excited to be a part of the program and for the possibilities that await. Let's GOOOO!

COMMENT 1: SO. MUCH. VALUE. HERE. 
üôåüôåüôåüî•üî•üî•üî•

Thank you for sharing, Jill Raibley Howery!!!

COMMENT 2: I love how you‚Äôre already applying this to your future customers and gaining insight. 

Gaining trust and demonstrating value takes time and a few touch points ‚Äî and that‚Äôs ok. 

I have a hunch you‚Äôre going to blow your initial expectations for your business out of the water! üëèüèº

For people with independent contractors working for them‚Ä¶. Do you have weekly or even monthly zoom meetings?

Is it legal to require a meeting without paying a contractor for it or do I need to make a meeting rate and pay everyone to attend?

Wondering what method works for team communication on a ‚Äúremote‚Äù team.

comments.text: I pay mine whenever we meet.  As mentioned above we can‚Äôt legally require attendance at the meetings (that gets into the definition of employee). I pay a bit less for meetings.  I normally send mass emails out and only have meetings if needed.  My admin also does ‚Äúcheck-in‚Äù with IC to address any issues.

I am a contractor working for two different companies (HH & OP mobile). It‚Äôs not legal to require meetings and not pay a contractor. My rate for meetings is different than my pay per visit patient visit rate. Both provide zoom options or I could go in person. One company I work for meetings are optional (I attended once & didn‚Äôt get much from it & haven‚Äôt attended again). The other, I try to attended weekly since it‚Äôs an interactive checkin for clinic health & growth. Occasionally I‚Äôll miss it if my patient schedule is packed & I need to start my day early. 

During the week we use an app/site called slack for communication.

Reimbursement Question: 
I had a patient ask how they would receive insurance reimbursement if they paid for services out of pocket using their FSA card.  Will it be received the same way as if services were paid for using a normal credit card?

comments.text:
When I see a cash based provider, I pay in full with my HSA card, and then I submit the superbill and my insurance reimburses my HSA if it was a covered service. 

I pay $55 for a chiro visit, my HSA gets reimbursed $15 for the visit because that's what they "allow" 

It's a pain in the tush, but it is what it is. üòâ 

As the consumer, I'm doing the leg-work to get some insurance coverage instead of having the provider do the work.
A person puts money into an FSA for the purpose of spending it on medical services.  I'm not sure why they would expect to get reimbursed for spending their money?

full_thread_text:

I pay $55 for a chiro visit, my HSA gets reimbursed $15 for the visit because that's what they "allow" 

It's a pain in the tush, but it is what it is. üòâ 

As the consumer, I'm doing the leg-work to get some insurance coverage instead of having the provider do the work.

post_text:
How to properly set your ‚Äúcash‚Äù price to reach your practice goals!

This was a comment made on a post that seemed to be helpful to others so I will share in more detail here:

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs helpful to set your price based on competition in the area, I think it makes a lot more sense to set your price based on the goals you have for yourself individually and in the practice. 

So, let‚Äôs look at this together:

Step 1: What so you want to bring home per year after taxes? 

In this example I will use $100,000 (that‚Äôs take home after taxes, that would be pretty awesome right?! Well, it‚Äôs totally possible, let‚Äôs keep going‚Ä¶)

Step 2: Figure out how much you would need to bring in TOTAL (gross revenue for the year) using this calculation:

7/10   $100,000/x (picture below)

Example: $142,857

Step 3: Divide by 48 weeks (because you should absolutely be taking 4 weeks off per year as a business owner to make this thing sustainable üëäüèª)

Example= $2,976 per week

Step 4: What is your ‚Äúsweet spot‚Äù for number of visits per week that you could maintain as a solo preneur (for now, until you hire if that‚Äôs a goal of yours)

Example= $2976/18 visits per week

= $165/visit

So, that means that you cannot charge anything less than $165 per visit (even with packages) in order to hit your personal goals.

Remember: If your cup is full, then you will be able to overflow into the lives of others and make the impact you are looking for. 

Hope this is helpful for you üëäüèª. 

Keep going. Don‚Äôt stop. Embrace the unknown.

comments.text: I now use 44 weeks per year in my equations.  My awesome boss thought I needed more PTO ü§£

The key: 
Don‚Äôt set your price based on competition.

post_text: I know PTs can‚Äôt order X-rays and have them reimbursed for insurance, but is there anything that says we can‚Äôt own X-ray machines and charge cash?

comments.text: I think the bigger question you should be asking is, someone gets injured and maybe breaks a bone, are they gonna call their PT or go to an emergency department? I've told people to go to urgent care over fractured collar bones (which are 99%+ non-op) and everyone still insists on going to the ED even though collar bone fractures are not life threatening. So imagin is a moot point. PTs no matter what will always be one of the last places people to go for a radiograph. While we can manage a lot of injuries, splinting and casting is not in this tool kit and the patient still needs to be referred out. (knowing what you don't know and when to refer in itself is a sign of expertise). If you're looking to push for added income, there are better places to look. The cost of a machine vs return on investment seems like we'd have to do multiple unnecessary images to even break even. Not to mention the unnecessary radiation this exposes patients and staff to. Also, our profession needs to focus on the issues that already exist like fighting third parties who steal our income, dealing with prior authorization processes that are impossible, making referral for profit illegal, etc......so many better things to focus on.

That‚Äôs a tough one, check your state laws. I‚Äôm betting to say no. Diagnostics equipment has been getting more cost effective. I think this should be an agenda for the APTA , they should get on the ball for certification classes to allow competent PTs to read X-ray ( think rural health). Ultrasound for imaging services as well. Good question though. And can‚Äôt compare with chiro , they have extensive knowledge on imaging compared to a DPT . Gotta give credit where credit is due.

While we can manage a lot of injuries, splinting and casting is not in this tool kit and the patient still needs to be referred out. (knowing what you don't know and when to refer in itself is a sign of expertise). If you're looking to push for added income, there are better places to look. The cost of a machine vs return on investment seems like we'd have to do multiple unnecessary images to even break even. Not to mention the unnecessary radiation this exposes patients and staff to. Also, our profession needs to focus on the issues that already exist like fighting third parties who steal our income, dealing with prior authorization processes that are impossible, making referral for profit illegal, etc......so many better things to focus on.

COMMENT 2: That‚Äôs a tough one, check your state laws. I‚Äôm betting to say no. Diagnostics equipment has been getting more cost effective. post_text:
‚ÄúHow much should I pay my employees?‚Äù

This is always a question that I‚Äôm fascinated by the answers people respond with. 

Without outright saying it the general consensus is to pay what you can get away with. To squeeze profits out of employees. 

If you‚Äôre a business owner, how‚Äôd that work out for you when you were working for someone else? They squeezed you for as much profit as they could get and you felt burnt out, frustrated, taken advantage of, disrespected and more.

And that‚Äôs the answer that we‚Äôre going to go with when we run a business? To take advantage of the next generation of therapists who don‚Äôt know better?

I just heard a quote that trauma that‚Äôs unhealed is repeated. Let‚Äôs be a part of breaking the cycle not repeating it.

comments.text: All of this is true. You need to pay them their worth and you also need to make sure you‚Äôre making at least 20-25% profit. You can‚Äôt just look at reimbursement related to pay to your contractor. As a business owner, you have other overhead to consider: EMR, rent, supplies and most importantly, risk. Be fair to them and be fair to yourself. A business that breaks even is not a business.

Good discussion point and very timely,  as I'm offering full time positions,  lol. I always felt that when I had a business,  I would pay fairly, and  better as the business did well. I also like the idea of base pay, but opportunity to earn more by doing more.  
Since you started the discussion,  I would love to hear others' ideas of pay, benefits and other rewards that keep employees engaged and happy.

full_thread_text:

This is always a question that I‚Äôm fascinated by the answers people respond with.

If you‚Äôre a business owner, how‚Äôd that work out for you when you were working for someone else? They squeezed you for as much profit as they could get and you felt burnt out, frustrated, taken advantage of, disrespected and more.

Be fair to them and be fair to yourself. A business that breaks even is not a business.

Since you started the discussion,  I would love to hear others' ideas of pay, benefits and other rewards that keep employees engaged and happy.

post_text:
Looking for some insight‚Ä¶ Working towards opening a mobile neuro PT practice. For those of you who also treat under this umbrella‚Ä¶ 
1.) How much do you charge your clients for your evals and how much for subsequent treatment sessions? 
2.) Is your current rate the rate at which you started your practice under? If not, at what point did you increase your rate?
3.) If you offer treatment packages, what do those look like?

comments.text: I have my NCS and am PWR! certified and have my own mobile neuro focused practice. Being that majority of my patients have Medicare, I decided to enroll in Medicare as we are unable to charge cash for formal physical therapy services. I do offer cash based physical therapy for those with private insurance and have a few that I bill as an out-of-network provider. I have not changed my rate yet as I feel those who have neurologic dx their income is typically fixed and I will most likely be seeing them over the course of a long period of time. I also offer cash based wellness services after I discharge patients from formal PT services. I'm happy to speak more regarding my practice if you'd like.

I know this isn‚Äôt what you asked but I will say I haven‚Äôt talked to a successful cash mobile provider who didn‚Äôt wish they started at a higher rate. 

There is no benefit to filling your schedule with low price treatments. 

Your goal isn‚Äôt being busy. Your goal is helping people. 

$200 or more for any home visit might be a reasonable minimum. 

It is always easier to start high and discount than to start low and raise.

Man, I hope this ends up being a trend, but people seem to be quite alright with doing my 1-on-1 private pay $170 per 1-hr eval and $130 or less for 45-min follow-up sessions depending on whether they got a package after the evaluation. Another couple new private pay evals lined up, one being a referral from the physiatrist. Evidently if you give people great care some don‚Äôt care what you charge and are willing to pay for it. 

I know this is less than many of y‚Äôall charge, but in my area people are charging $115-175/hr for evals so me being at $170 already places me at the top vs in the middle of the area market when I was located much farther away from home. 

ü§û This WOM fire keeps spreading! Also I got one lead from auto-scheduler from my website that converted recently as well which was exciting. 

It‚Äôs been a slow build up process, but I think I can finally see the light. I‚Äòm glad because rent is going to be much more burdensome soon enough.

post_text:
Question for those who do aquatic therapy, specifically group. How are you managing the billing? And how is reimbursement rate for you?  

Is it self pay or are you able to bill their insurances?

comments.text: When I did my 1st rotation at an outpt with aquatics we did group for Medicare and 1:1 for private pay

Aquatic therapy is a risk activity; Group therapy is a risk activity. Know the payor rules, know the code definitions, and setup "monitoring" activity as part of the practices Compliance Auditing & Monitoring Plan.  üôÇ 

As for CMS, there is also published policy on "pools" depending CMS enrollment (private practice v. rehab agency).

full_thread_text:
POST: Question for those who do aquatic therapy, specifically group. How are you managing the billing? And how is reimbursement rate for you?  

Is it self pay or are you able to bill their insurances?

COMMENT 1: When I did my 1st rotation at an outpt with aquatics we did group for Medicare and 1:1 for private pay

COMMENT 2: Aquatic therapy is a risk activity; Group therapy is a risk activity. Know the payor rules, know the code definitions, and setup "monitoring" activity as part of the practices Compliance Auditing & Monitoring Plan.  üôÇ 

As for CMS, there is also published policy on "pools" depending CMS enrollment (private practice v. rehab agency).

post_text:
Since this group is truely a plethora of knowledge, I am hoping to get some guidance as I approach a job interview. Long story short, I am wondering if full time cash based PTs are getting a salary similar to PTs working in insurance based clinics? 

I have 10 years experience as a PT and my OCS. I have worked for a cash based company (part time). I did not get to the conversation of what a full time salary would look like. In 2020 I began seeing my own patients when I was laid off, and I  pushed ahead working for myself. 

As much as I would love to continue my own cash based practice growth, I am in a situation where my financial health needs serious help. I am looking to move in with family across the country. I have an in-person interview lined up with what I am hoping is a dream job: cash based company with 8 locations advertising that they provide elite level services.

I was told to expect a salary that is on par with local insurance based clinics for this job. (I was given an exact # but am unsure if it‚Äôs appropriate to post) It‚Äôs in an expensive part of the country and I worry that I will still struggle to support myself. Considering that I haven‚Äôt worked full time in over 5 years, I am out fo practice with how to negotiate more for myself in a respectful way. ÔøºÔøºI was a tad shocked at the proposed salary because without taking insurances, and having to deal with declining reimbursement rates, I expected the pay to be a bit more. But perhaps I am just uninformed. I hope that it is acceptable for me to ask here if cash pay clinics hiring full time employees tend to provide very similar salaries as those that are insurance based?

I understand that overhead, benefits, etc all add up, and that this might be a very fair salary. Until I started my own small practice and was doing the math myself, I didn‚Äôt understand the cash flow of clinics. Now I find it empowering to understand. And most importantly, if there are appropriate questions or proposals that I could make to increase my salary potential, while being respectful to the business as a whole, I would love to learn from those who have been in a similar situation. Thanks for your help.

comments.text:
I own my own brick and mortar cash clinic right now, and previously worked for a cash based clinic as an employee. 

When I was an employee I made 44% of my revenue. I worked for a company who had several offices across the company, maybe 6? They provided no real benefits, health insurance was expensive and no PTO. Mathematically this wound up being  75-80k a year salary before taxes. In my area, other OP Ortho job offers I was getting at the time were all in the 60-65k range. I like in Denver (high cost of living, poor reimbursement).

A year ago I opened my own cash practice. With overhead (including rent in an expensive part of town), my estimated take home, after taxes, will be between 80-90k this year. So a big step up to say the least.
A company with 8 offices prob. Has a lot of wasted expenses like middle mangers etc.  May want to look at a single locattion office

post_text: Hiring my first Cash Based clinic PT. What's a fair percentage of compensation of the total per visit rate? Any help would be greatly appreciated!

comments.text: I think it depends on your session cost, your overhead, and how much you are wanting to make off of your staff. I give my contractor 65% which ends up giving me about $20-30 a session after paying rent, expenses, etc.

No offense to anyone above, but if you have a brick and mortar clinic (as opposed to the lower overhead mobile model)Ôøº, you are shooting yourself in the foot if you‚Äôre paying staff much more than 40% of revenue generated. ÔøºÔøº Overhead adds up quickly and you could soon be at small enough margins that you don‚Äôt give yourself wiggle room and opportunity to invest enough into advertising and other costs of growth.Ôøº 

If you charge adequately for your services, you can stick with these percentages and still pay (and empower) your therapist as much or more than anyone in your area. I pay better than any popts clinic in Austin and my therapists only see one patient per hour.

Ôøº

full_thread_text:
POST: Hiring my first Cash Based clinic PT. What's a fair percentage of compensation of the total per visit rate? Any help would be greatly appreciated!

COMMENT 1: I think it depends on your session cost, your overhead, and how much you are wanting to make off of your staff. I give my contractor 65% which ends up giving me about $20-30 a session after paying rent, expenses, etc.

COMMENT 2: No offense to anyone above, but if you have a brick and mortar clinic (as opposed to the lower overhead mobile model)Ôøº, you are shooting yourself in the foot if you‚Äôre paying staff much more than 40% of revenue generated. ÔøºÔøº Overhead adds up quickly and you could soon be at small enough margins that you don‚Äôt give yourself wiggle room and opportunity to invest enough into advertising and other costs of growth.Ôøº 

If you charge adequately for your services, you can stick with these percentages and still pay (and empower) your therapist as much or more than anyone in your area. I pay better than any popts clinic in Austin and my therapists only see one patient per hour.

Ôøº

post_text: How do you figure out what a comparable salary is for an employee vs a contractor rate?

comments.text:
Assuming payment model is the same, so looking at hourly versus hourly or paper visit versus paper visit, a fair contractor rate would be 1.075 times the fair W-2 rate. 

Now, if you are asking about the difference between pay per visit 1099 versus salary W-2, that‚Äôs a tougher question and it‚Äôs going to depend on a few things, namely stability of the caseload. Generally speaking, by taking someone under a paper visit model versus an hourly or salary model, you are ensuring yourself against declining caseload, and you have to pay a premium for that insurance In the form of increased labor cost
Start out with whether you can legally hire a contractor or not before you deal with rates.

full_thread_text:

Now, if you are asking about the difference between pay per visit 1099 versus salary W-2, that‚Äôs a tougher question and it‚Äôs going to depend on a few things, namely stability of the caseload. Generally speaking, by taking someone under a paper visit model versus an hourly or salary model, you are ensuring yourself against declining caseload, and you have to pay a premium for that insurance In the form of increased labor cost

COMMENT 2: Start out with whether you can legally hire a contractor or not before you deal with rates.

post_text: Hi everyone. I am about to become a private practice cash based owner. Having some difficulty setting rates for PT service. Can anyone suggest rates for IE and follow up visits??  Package rate and what a package may consist of??  Live in Savannah. Ga   Thanks.

comments.text: Hi Lisa, we spoke earlier üòä we are also in GA. My husband was doing $150 eval and $120 per visit but changing to $150 for all visits now. We tried packages but it didn‚Äôt work as great as per visit since we work with older population and often they have changes in their conditions, required hospitalizations for other reasons, etc. I hope it helps üòä

I strongly encourage you to reverse engineer your rates.

How much do you want to gross per year? Divide that by 48 weeks, then by how many treatment hours you want to complete per week, and you'll have your per session anchor.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi everyone. I am about to become a private practice cash based owner. Having some difficulty setting rates for PT service. Can anyone suggest rates for IE and follow up visits??  Package rate and what a package may consist of??  Live in Savannah. Ga   Thanks.

We tried packages but it didn‚Äôt work as great as per visit since we work with older population and often they have changes in their conditions, required hospitalizations for other reasons, etc. I hope it helps üòä

COMMENT 2: I strongly encourage you to reverse engineer your rates.

How much do you want to gross per year? Divide that by 48 weeks, then by how many treatment hours you want to complete per week, and you'll have your per session anchor.

post_text:
Hello everyone! 

I have a quick question. One of my patients approach me and asked me to provide private PT @ home in NYC after he run out of his Medicare B service.
 
What‚Äôs the legal and ethical way or procedure to start cash base (private pay)physical therapy services at home for Medicare B patients in NY after they already reach their market cap and wanted PT via private pay (out of pocket) . 

Can anyone clear my following doubts ..

1. Can I legally work with Med B as cash pay(out of pocket)..?

2. I have to get ABN form signed before I start as private pay for med B home care patient  ..!? Right

3. Or I have to sign any other wellness waiver form instead of ABN?

4. If work as private pay do I have to do documentation for PT treatment..?

Any information would be greatly appreciated along with format or any attachment for any form. 

Any suggestions on this would be greatly appreciated , as I am new to this private pay/cased base practice .

Thanks in advance .üôèüèª

comments.text: Firstly there is no cap. Medicare covers medically necessary skilled therapy services.  You can charge cash for services that are not covered by Medicare or do not meet the above criteria. If it is something that Medicare would normally cover but would not be covered in this case you would complete an ABN with the client prior to beginning services. For services Medicare would not normally cover e.g. dry needling or fitness program you would use your usual waiver. If it is skilled therapy that meets that criteria then it must be billed to Medicare. Therapists are not allowed to opt out and there is a mandatory claims submission requirement.

Milena Ryes  Thanks for your response. Yes I am providing PT under Medicare as I m working under private company as staff position. Yes patient  was trying to approach me for maintenance , I like your point for simple wellness note. What do you mean by do me t on simple wellness note..?Do you have format of simple wellness note ..? If yes can you please attach it over here..?

post_text:
Getting the practice going has been extremely stressful, but I just got one hell of a motivator from my first reimbursement from BCBS-UT. They paid me $241 for 1 eval of 5 units, 1 untimed eval code + 4 timed codes of about 10 min each. They are one of the highest payors in UT so I understand all insurances won‚Äôt be like that and evals pay a lot more, but even at the SNF I only make $47/hr or $35/hr OP Ortho PP. Even after taxes, overhead costs, and paying out 6% to a billing company that is substantially more per hour, and I get to treat in the setting I want to be in with the types of patients I want to treat. I‚Äôm also going to be pushing the cash pay side hard as well which doesn‚Äôt require me to pay out to a billing company so my per hour reimbursement will be higher there. 

If I needed a sign that I‚Äôm making the right decision to go out on my own I just got one. That got me fired up! üî•
#LetsGo
#DreamBig

comments.text: Brian Collins, how do you learn which insurance companies use CMS 8 minute rule vs. SPM rule of 8's?  I've spent hours on BCBS & CIGNAs website trying to find out their policy.

That‚Äôs awesome but just for everyone to be aware that Blue Cross Blue Shield has different reimbursement rates in the different states. For us Blue Cross Blue Shield has awesome reimbursement rates in one state we are in and horrible in the next.Ôøº

post_text: Quick question about Medicare self pay with ABN: I‚Äôm transitioning a patient to self pay in the next several weeks. As far as self pay rates for Medicare beneficiaries, is there a requirement that I charge the Medicare allowable rate for whatever CPT code I would be performing? For example, I plan on just doing exercising and kinesiotaping, and I‚Äôll probably be there 30-40 min. Do I have to bill the equivalent of 2 or 3 units of the Medicare allowable for therex?

comments.text:
#Compliance #ABN  "transitioning"  - what does this mean?  

Is the beneficiary completing their medically necessary POC? 

If so discharge patient and setup a "wellness" or "exercise" program.  A mandatory ABN is not necessary, an optional ABN is recommended (read instructions relative to therapy). 

Are you "stepping down" the frequency, w/beneficiary requesting to maintain frequency?  If so, issue Mandatory ABN (coded to claim) to transfer liability to beneficiary.

My strong suggestion - review ABN instructions (both ABN general instructions and ABN therapy specific guidance).

As for billing for Mandatory ABN - guidance in the instructions - Medicare does not dictate price, only HOW price is stated. Setting rates best practice....?? 

As for billing Optional ABN - Medicare does not dictate rates.

For ABN - always use #GoToSource information - for both ABN and therapy application of ABN. 

Best of luck.

If you are seeing a Medicare beneficiary and doing something that is skilled you cannot charge cash for that service.  If it‚Äôs a non skilled service you can and charge whatever you want.  
If you have no relationship with Medicare - ie they don‚Äôt know you exist, then there is no way for you to bill Medicare in which case charge whatever you want.

For example, I plan on just doing exercising and kinesiotaping, and I‚Äôll probably be there 30-40 min. Do I have to bill the equivalent of 2 or 3 units of the Medicare allowable for therex?

COMMENT 1: #Compliance #ABN  "transitioning"  - what does this mean?  

Is the beneficiary completing their medically necessary POC? 

If so discharge patient and setup a "wellness" or "exercise" program.  A mandatory ABN is not necessary, an optional ABN is recommended (read instructions relative to therapy). 

Are you "stepping down" the frequency, w/beneficiary requesting to maintain frequency?  If so, issue Mandatory ABN (coded to claim) to transfer liability to beneficiary.

My strong suggestion - review ABN instructions (both ABN general instructions and ABN therapy specific guidance).

As for billing for Mandatory ABN - guidance in the instructions - Medicare does not dictate price, only HOW price is stated. Setting rates best practice....?? 

As for billing Optional ABN - Medicare does not dictate rates.

For ABN - always use #GoToSource information - for both ABN and therapy application of ABN. 

Best of luck.

COMMENT 2: If you are seeing a Medicare beneficiary and doing something that is skilled you cannot charge cash for that service.  If it‚Äôs a non skilled service you can and charge whatever you want.  
If you have no relationship with Medicare - ie they don‚Äôt know you exist, then there is no way for you to bill Medicare in which case charge whatever you want.

post_text:
Those of ya‚Äôll that bill OON:

How do you bill patients with high deductibles without their wallets getting absolutely murdered by higher charges? Do you cap your max charges at your self-pay price? Does that fall under the ‚ÄúGood Faith Estimate‚Äù? I want to bill a patient with UHC OON, but my billing team said my reimbursement would be almost double my cash-pay price of $170/visit and considering the patient had a $5000 deductible they eat all of that unless I‚Äôm mistaken which I certainly could be.

comments.text: You can't undervalue what you offer. I know it's tough, but have the conversation with them and just be honest. Tell them that going cash will save them money in the long run. We are OON with UHC, as well, and I just had this conversation today with someone. She elected to go cash and see me because we have a relationship and she values my honesty.
Be consistent with your policies and your billing. Make sure they are written out and then put them in the Good Faith Estimate. This includes what your normal fees are, your prompt pay discount.

post_text:
I have a billing question for anyone who does both mobile and in-clinic visits. I recently expanded my in-clinic availability with new space, and so decided to increase my mobile rate by $20 - partly to cover gas, partly for the lost time with driving compared to in-clinic visits, and partly to encourage more scheduling of in-clinic visits versus mobile. 
My question is - I'm not sure how to change this/how this should look in my documentation, specifically on my superbills/invoices. My thought was that I should keep my per-unit rate the same, and just add the $20 as an additional fee - however, there doesn't seem to be any way to do this across the board in my documentation (PT Everywhere), I think I would have to go into each visit invoice and add the fee, which I don't really want to do because (a) it seems less transparent - I want to make sure patients see that additional fee from the beginning if they're scheduling online, and (b) time-consuming.
Has anyone else run into a similar issue? How did you set yours up?
Thanks all!

comments.text: I use PtE as well. Question: Why are you trying to make your per unit rate equal you total visit rate? PtE let's you set whatever price you want. Ignore your per unit rate unless you are billing OON insurance. PtE let's you set the flat rate at whatever you want. Create a "Mobile PT Visit" service and add the $20 to the service price. You don't even to notify the patient you are charging more. When they go to book they will see the mobile visit is more expensive than the in clinic visit. They might not care or they might decide to come in clinic. I'd recommend setting up a new appointment type and charging more for it
My population is mainly Medicare so I cannot charge a fee for mobile versus clinic

full_thread_text:
POST: I have a billing question for anyone who does both mobile and in-clinic visits. I recently expanded my in-clinic availability with new space, and so decided to increase my mobile rate by $20 - partly to cover gas, partly for the lost time with driving compared to in-clinic visits, and partly to encourage more scheduling of in-clinic visits versus mobile. 
My question is - I'm not sure how to change this/how this should look in my documentation, specifically on my superbills/invoices. My thought was that I should keep my per-unit rate the same, and just add the $20 as an additional fee - however, there doesn't seem to be any way to do this across the board in my documentation (PT Everywhere), I think I would have to go into each visit invoice and add the fee, which I don't really want to do because (a) it seems less transparent - I want to make sure patients see that additional fee from the beginning if they're scheduling online, and (b) time-consuming.
Has anyone else run into a similar issue? How did you set yours up?
Thanks all!

COMMENT 1: I use PtE as well. Question: Why are you trying to make your per unit rate equal you total visit rate? PtE let's you set whatever price you want. Ignore your per unit rate unless you are billing OON insurance. PtE let's you set the flat rate at whatever you want. Create a "Mobile PT Visit" service and add the $20 to the service price. You don't even to notify the patient you are charging more. When they go to book they will see the mobile visit is more expensive than the in clinic visit. They might not care or they might decide to come in clinic. I'd recommend setting up a new appointment type and charging more for it

COMMENT 2: My population is mainly Medicare so I cannot charge a fee for mobile versus clinic
