post_text:
Help needed:

I have a cash based business where I specialize working with runners and triathletes. I do a lot of wellness visits /running evaluations. I had someone reach out to me who lives over an hour away and asked if I have a surcharge fee for going that far and I wanted to get everybody‚Äôs opinion on how much you‚Äôd recommend charging. With gas being so expensive and extra time driving that far wanted to be fair. I charge $130 for a basic evaluation and typically $150 for a separate running evaluation with fully analysis. 

Thank you!

comments.text:
$130-150/hr normal rate 

Driving to/from will be two hours of your time not including business expense of mileage on vehicle and gas. 

Definitely charge for time and expenses. 

Something like 20% of normal service charge for out of radius visits plus $.05/mile?

Or just a flat rate that changes with the market if you want simplicity
I wouldn't charge extra. Think of it as an extra marketing and extra word of mouth. Another person changed. Good luck my friend!

post_text:
A friend posted this today in our Leaders Network & I loved it *

You graduate college with 100k in debt, people clap and cheer for you. 

You get married and spend between 5-50k for one day, people will clap and cheer for you.

You take a 200k loan from the bank to buy your first house, people will clap and cheer for you. 

You take a loan for 30 - 40k for a car (a depreciating asset) with an interest rate, people will clap and cheer for you. 

Thats 500,000 in total debt that MOST people are living in, and somehow they are feeling good about it because people are congratulating them for it. 

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

Now, go and tell those same people you spent a few hundred dollars to start your own business......

‚ÄúAre you sure?‚Äù 
‚ÄúWhat if it doesn‚Äôt work?‚Äù
‚ÄúCan you get your money back?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat if people laugh at you?‚Äù

Picture a bucket full of crabs with no lid. The moment a crab tries to get out, the other crabs will literally rip its legs off to keep it in the bucket with them. 

This year, pay attention to who you‚Äôre surrounding yourself with and who‚Äôs speaking into your life. 

To my fellow entrepreneurs, STOP WORRYING ABOUT WHAT OTHERS THINK AND KEEP PROMOTING YOUR BUSINESS. You got this üôåüèΩüíÖüèΩüí™üèΩ‚ú®

comments.text: Love this. We all need to hear this!!! It can be so hard sometimes and easy to doubt yourself. Thank you Fitzherbert Harry

Living this and loving it‚ù£Ô∏è

Thank you for sharing Fitzherbert Harry.

post_text:
My husband & I are looking at relocating in near future. Based on some work opportunity research (he‚Äôs a physician and I‚Äôm a PT) & our personal interests research, we are considering NC or CO in mainland v/s Honolulu. Comparing these options. Currently, have my concierge & telehealth practice in CA. 
I‚Äôd really appreciate if any of you PTs here who are PT business owners and/or employees in these states and are willing to chat with me for more information work related opportunities, growth, need for PTs, business friendly laws/regulations, insurance credentialing, and a summary of overall lifestyle, pros/cons. I can only find so much info online and reading statistics and realtors but I want some profession specific info apart from overall from you guys. Any input, thoughts, feedback or DM me is greatly appreciated!
Thank you so much üòä

comments.text: I didn‚Äôt own my practice until I moved out of NC, but lived there for 6.5 years as a PT and unlimited direct access laws are one pro of being a PT there. It‚Äôs growing quickly, especially the research triangle area, but still better cost of living than many other states, and there‚Äôs a good pipeline of PT schools in the area and generally people wanting to move there, which is good if you‚Äôre hiring.

I worked in Colorado (Denver metro) in a hospital. 
1. We LOVE denver/Colorado. The weather is amazing, there is anything you could want to do, the mountains of course, such an active lifestyle state. 
2. Denver is EXPENSIVE. housing is ridiculous, daycare is ridiculous. 
3. Pay can be less. I was told by my employer (and many people are told the same), ‚Äúthe mountains/the Colorado lifestyle is part of your benefits package üòë not really if it‚Äôs difficult to afford cost of living. 
That being said I‚Äôm sure there is a huge market for mobile or small business PTs. There are a lot of successful people who would be willing to pay cash/more if they get better. I will say there is an overwhelming amount of PTs, because of multiple PT schools, and of course the active lifestyle so it is definitely over saturated but I‚Äôm not sure what the indep mobile/small business looks like. We left January 2019 because of husband job opportunity and cost of living/daycare but our goal is to finish paying off loans and go back with kids out of daycare!!
